revision.text:
{{Infobox family | colour = lightgrey | name = Grill | crest = [[File:Grillska vapenskölden Österbybruk Sverige.jpg|275px]] | caption = The Grill family coat of arms at the Österbybruk manor | ethnicity = Swedish | birth_place = | region = | early_forms = | origin = [[Genoa]], Italy | members = {{plain list| *Abraham Grill (I) the Elder *Johan Abraham Grill *Claes Grill (I) *[[Jean Abraham Grill]] *Claes Grill (II) *Adolf Ulric Grill }} | otherfamilies = | distinctions = Prominent in trade, manufacturing and politics | traditions = | heirlooms = | estate = Numerous during the 18th century and 19th century | meaning = | footnotes = Motto: ''Honesty is the best policy.'' }} [[File:Porslins-tallrik med Grillska vapnet.jpg|thumb|275px|Chinese porcelain dish with the Grill coat of arms, imported to Sweden by the SOIC.]] The '''Grill family''' was one of several Swedish families having significant influence with the [[Swedish East India Company]] (SOIC). During the 17th century, 18th century and for some years into the 19th century, they owned [[ironworks]] and mills manufacturing goods for export while operating wharfs, textile companies, saw mills and other factories related to shipbuilding. Several Grills were directors of the SOIC and the Grill firm traded with the merchants in Canton (now known as [[Guangzhou]]) as members of the SOIC and privately. The Grills owned houses, manors and estates at a number of locations in Sweden. All the noted Grills were in some way connected to the main Grill Trading House, and several other companies were established in association with the Trading House. The Grill name was kept and passed on through the generations and some of the Grills even shared the same first name. Apart from the SOIC, the Grills are most noted for their contribution to the Swedish [[Ferrous metallurgy|iron industry]] and for exports of iron during the 18th century. == Origin == [[File:Sevenbom, Svindersvik.jpg|thumb|275px|Svindersvik, one of the estates owned by one of the Grills, with the SOIC flag {{efn|The swallow-tailed version of the Swedish flag was used on the ships of the SOIC even though the use of such a flag was prohibited. Only ships in the Swedish Navy were entitled to fly a (triple-)tailed flag. The SOIC ships used the two-tailed version, that looked like a navy flag, to discourage pirates at sea. Despite the prohibition, Claes Grill (I) ordered several flags in Canton.{{sfn|Kjellberg|1975|pp=174–176}} He even used them at his summer residence, Svindersvik, on land and on the rowboat taking him to and from the house. One of these flags remained at Svindersvik and is one of the oldest, preserved flags in Sweden. {{As of|2014}} it is kept at the ''[[Livrustkammaren]]''.{{cite book |last=Söderberg|first=Bengt G.|date=1968|title=Slott och herresäten i Sverige. Södermanland.|trans-title=Castles and manors in Sweden. Södermanland|id={{LIBRIS|483512}}|location=Malmö|publisher=Allhems förlag|pages=170–171|language=Swedish}}}}]] Originating in [[Genoa]], Italy, part of the family moved to [[Augsburg]], Germany where on 29{{nbsp}}July 1571, Andreas Grill received [[burgher arms]] with their own [[coat of arms]].{{cite web|title=En praktfull ostindisk servis med det grillska vapnet|trans-title=A splendid East India tableware with the Grill coat of arms|url=http://www.digitaltmuseum.se/things/en-praktfull-ostindisk-servis-med-det/S-NM/NMA.0029080|website=www.digitaltmuseum.se|publisher=Digitalt Museum—[[Nordic Museum]]|accessdate=27 July 2014}}{{cite web|title=Grilliana – En sida om släkten Grill|trans-title=Grillology – A page about the Grill family|url=http://grilliana.wordpress.com/historia/vapenbrevet/|website=www.grilliana.wordpress.com|publisher=The Grill family|accessdate=27 July 2014}} from the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. The name Grill comes from the Italian ''Grillo'', meaning cricket, while the family's coat of arms displays a crane holding a cricket in its beak.{{efn|Shield:Or, standing on a triple mount sable, a crane holding a cricket on its beak proper.{{cite journal |title=Ett fosterländskt Bildergalleri. |trans-title=A patriotic picture gallery. |last=Schöldström |first=Birger |journal=Svenska Familj-Journalen |year=1879 |publisher=Svenska Familj-Journalen via Project Runeberg | url=http://runeberg.org/famijour/1879/0329.html |volume=18 |pages=325–327 |language=Swedish |location=Stockholm }}}} The family came to Sweden with the arrival of the silversmith Anthoni Grill (I), grandson of Andreas Grill, born in Augsburg and from 1638, a [[Burgess (title)|burgess]] in [[Amsterdam]]. He was the ''Riksguardie'' (National Appraiser) for the [[Myntverket]] in 1658 to 1667, where he supervised the making of coins and made sure that [[measurement]]s were standardized throughout Sweden. He was not especially good at his work and in 1663, he was demoted to handle smaller goods in gold and silver. He was succeeded at the Myntverket by his son Anthoni Grill (II), who also bought the Grill house at [[Stortorget]] in Stockholm.{{cite encyclopedia |title =Grill, släkt |trans-title=Grill, family| encyclopedia =[[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon]] | year =1967–1969 |publisher =[[National Archives of Sweden]] |location =Stockholm |language=Swedish |volume=17 |page=276 |url =http://sok.riksarkivet.se/sbl/artikel/13191 }} During the 18th century the family was described as members of the ''Skeppsbroadeln'' (the Skeppsbro Nobility). The name was coined during the 18th century and referred to the wealthiest merchant families in Stockholm at that time, especially those who lived by the quays along the [[Skeppsbron]].{{cite web|title=Skeppsbroadeln|trans-title=Skeppsbro nobility|url=http://www.ne.se/skeppsbroadeln|website=www.ne.se|publisher=''[[Nationalencyklopedin]]''|language=Swedish|accessdate=16 September 2014}} The family consisted of two branches —the [[Garphyttan]] branch and the [[Godegård]] branch. The Grill family is included in the ''[[Ointroducerad Adels Förening]]'' (Association of the Unintroduced Nobility), an association for Swedish citizens whose family was ennobled in a foreign country, as well as some families who were ennobled in Sweden but for some reason never introduced at the Swedish House of Nobility.{{cite book|last1=Müller|first1=Leos|title=The merchant houses of Stockholm, c. 1640–1800: a comparative study of early-modern entrepreneurial behaviour|date=1998|publisher=Acta Universitatis Upsaliensis|location=Uppsala|isbn=91-554-4233-1|series=Studia historica Upsaliensia, 0081-6531 ; 188Studia historica Upsaliensia, 0081-6531 ; 188|id={{LIBRIS|8359550}}}} == Family tree == A section of the Grill family tree showing some noted members. Numbers attached to some of the names do not form an official part of their name but are provided as a convenient way of referring to identically named Grills. {{chart top|width=100%}} {{chart/start|align=center|summary=The Grill family (part of)}} {{chart| | | | | |AG| | |AG='''Andreas Grill'''
(still alive in 1571)
wine merchant in Augsburg}} {{chart| | | | | | |!| | }} {{chart| | | | | |BG| | |BG='''Balthasar G'''
(died 1614)
goldsmith in Augsburg}} {{chart| | | | | | |!| | }} {{chart| | | | | |AG| | |AG='''Anthoni G (I)'''
(died 1675)
National appraiser for the Myntverket}} {{chart| | | | |,|-|^|-|-|.| | }} {{chart| | | |AG| | |BG| | |AG='''Anthoni G (II)'''
(died 1703)
Goldsmith and
National appraiser for the Myntverket|BG='''Baltzar G'''
(died 1697)
Director}} {{chart| | |,|-|^|-|-|.| | }} {{chart| |AG| | |CG| | |AG='''Abraham G (I)''' the Elder
(1674–1725)
Wholesaler in Stockholm|CG='''Carlos G'''
(died 1736)
Wholesaler in Stockholm}} {{chart| |,|^|-|-|v|-|-|-|-|-|-|v|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|.| }} {{chart|AG| |JAG| | | | |AntG| | | | | | |CG| |AG='''Abraham G (II)''' the Younger
(1707–68)
Director in Gothenburg|JAG='''Johan Abraham G'''
(1719–99)
Wholesaler in Stockholm|AntG='''Anthoni G (III)'''
(1705–83)
Wholesaler in Amsterdam|CG='''Claes G (I)'''
(1705–67)
Wholesaler in Stockholm}} {{chart|,|^|-|-|-|.| | |,|-|-|-|+|-|-|-|.| | | | |!| | }} {{chart|JAG| |CG| |JG| |AG| |AntG| |AUG| |JAG='''Jean Abraham G'''
(1736–92)
Ironwork owner, Godegård|CG='''Claes G (II)'''
(1750–1816)
Consul General in London|JG='''Jacob G'''
(1734–99)
Ironwork owner, Skebo|AG='''Abraham G (III)'''
(1735–1805)
Ironwork partner, Garphyttan|AntG='''Anthoni G (IV)'''
(1743–1805)
|AUG='''Adolph Ulric G'''
(1752–97)
Ironwork owner, Söderfors}} {{chart/end}} |- |style="text-align: left;"|'''Notes:''' {{notelist-lr}} {{chart bottom}} == Abraham Grill (I) the Elder == [[File:1674-1725-abraham-grill-da.jpg|thumb|Abraham Grill (I) the Elder.]] '''Abraham Grill''' (1674{{snd}}20 March 1725) was a Swedish merchant. Married three times, he had seven children and was the son of Anthoni (II) as well as heir to the Grill family fortune, which he increased through trade speculation. During the [[Great Northern War]] led by King [[Charles XII of Sweden|Charles XII]], he gave large sums of money to the state and during a time of famine he sold grains at reduced price to the needy. He was also the driving force behind the founding of a house for poor elderly widows in Stockholm on 14{{nbsp}}July 1724.{{cite encyclopedia | title =Grill | encyclopedia =[[Nordisk familjebok]]–Uggleupplagan |editor1=Meijer Bernhard |editor2=Westrin Theodor |editor3=Berg Ruben G:son |editor4=Söderberg Verner |editor5=Fahlstedt Eugène | year =1909 | publisher =Nordisk familjeboks förl. | url=http://runeberg.org/nfbj/0178.html | pp=303–304 | location =Stockholm | language=Swedish}} In 1716, he and his brother Carlos Grill, founded the Grill [[Joint-stock company|Trading House]]. The house traded mainly in [[wrought iron]] and became one of the leading trading houses in Stockholm during the 18th century.{{cite web|title=Handelshuset Carlos & Claes Grill (1716–1799)|trans-title=The Carlos & Claes Grill Trading House (1716–1799)|url=http://sok.riksarkivet.se/?Sokord=Abraham+Grill&FacettFilter=arkis_aukt_huvudkategori_facet%24F%C3%B6retag%3A&page=1&postid=Arkis+2BD0C626-62E9-471D-8C01-967559000D04&s=TARKIS08_Siv|website=www.riksarkivet.se/|publisher=[[National Archives of Sweden]]|accessdate=14 September 2014}} During its first year the company bought [[Land reclamation|reclaimed land]], from the Countess Elisabeth Oxenstierna, in the east part of Stockholm. The land was used to establish the Terra Nova Wharf,{{efn|''Terra Nova'' is Latin for "new land" and refers to the reclaimed land it was built upon.{{sfn|Zethelius|1956|p=59}}}} also known as the ''Köpmannavarvet'' (the Merchants Wharf),{{cite web|title=Strandvägshamnen|trans-title=Port at Strandvägen|url=http://www.stockholmshamnar.se/Historia/Platser/Stockholm/Strandvagshamnen/|website=www.stockholmshamnar.se|publisher=Stockholms Hamn|accessdate=14 September 2014}} where a number of the ships for the SOIC were built.{{sfn|Zethelius|1956|p=59}} When Abraham died in 1725, his share of the Trading House went to his son Claes (I). At the death of Carlos in 1736, Claes (I) was sole owner of the company until his half-brother Johan Abraham joined him as partner. Johan Abraham continued to run the Trading House after Claes (I)'s death in 1767. In 1799, Johan Abraham died and the company went bankrupt. == Abraham Grill (II) the Younger == '''Abraham Grill''' (28 January 1707{{snd}}28 January 1768) was the brother of Anthoni (III) and Claes (I), and half-brother to Johan Abraham. He started his career as Swedish [[Consul (representative)|consul]] in [[Helsingør]] in 1733 to 1736. During his time in Denmark he met Anna Maria Petersen, and they were married in 1735. They had thirteen children of which five died at an early age. Abraham and his family moved to Gothenburg in 1746, where he established a trading house. That year, he was also one of the directors for the SOIC during the second charter.{{sfn|Kjellberg|1975|p=165}} He cooperated closely with the two other trading houses in the Grill family at that time: Carlos & Claes Grill in Stockholm and Anthony & Johannes Grill in Amsterdam. Abraham's trading house handled most of the copper exported from Gothenburg during a few years in the 1760s. The company also exported iron and tea, brought to Gothenburg by the SOIC.{{cite web|last=Svensson|first=Anders|title=Abraham Grill|url=http://gamlagoteborg.se/2014/05/18/abraham-grill/|website=gamlagoteborg.se|publisher=Det Gamla Göteborg|accessdate=14 September 2014}} One of Abraham's many children, Lorentz Grill, became his partner in the trading house in 1761. At the death of Abraham (on his birthday) in 1768, Lorentz sought out new partners and continued running the company. == Johan Abraham Grill == [[File:Paret Grill.jpg|thumb|320px|Johan Abraham Grill and Christina Elisabeth Grill]] '''Johan Abraham Grill''' (1719{{snd}}16 March 1799) was a Swedish merchant and politician. He was the son of Abraham (I), the Elder, and Katarina Rozelius, half-brother to Claes (I) and uncle to Jean Abraham. He married Christina Elisabeth Fischer (1731–1805). It was Johan Abraham who introduced a motto for the Grill family: ''Ärlighet warar längst'' (Honesty is the best policy.). In 1747, Johan Abraham became partner in the Grill Trading House. Throughout his career he held a number of official positions and received several awards. In 1763, he became a board member in the ''Jernkontoret'' (The Iron Trade Association), established in 1747, it is the oldest [[trade association]] in Sweden. In 1767, he was a member of the ''Sjöförsäkringsrätten'' (The Naval Insurance Court) where he handled disputes related to shipping that could not be settled in any other way.{{cite web|title=Kungl. Sjöförsäkringsöverrätten (1750–1866)|trans-title=The Naval Insurance Court (1750–1866|url=http://sok.riksarkivet.se/?postid=Arkisref%20SE/RA/155&s=Balder|website=www.riksarkivet.se/|publisher=[[National Archives of Sweden]]|accessdate=12 August 2014}} With the third charter, he became director of the SOIC in 1770.{{sfn|Kjellberg|1975|p=166}} At the same time he was an accountant and also responsible for credits and loans issued from the Swedish State to various companies.{{cite web|title=Generaldiskontkontoret bildades 1787 som...|trans-title=The General Credit's Office was established in 1787 as...|url=http://svenskuppslagsbok.se/tag/generaldiskontkontoret/|website=svenskuppslagsbok.se|publisher=[[Svensk uppslagsbok]]|accessdate=12 August 2014}} Johan Abraham was a member of the [[Hats (party)|hat party]] and helped finance the Swedish court and the hats activity in the [[Riksdag]] 1771–72, especially in connection to King [[Gustav III of Sweden|Gustav III]]'s coup d'état on 19{{nbsp}}August 1772, whereby the king's power was solidified.{{cite encyclopedia |title=Gustav III |editor=Gunnar Carlquist |encyclopedia=Svensk uppslagsbok |year=1932 |publisher=Baltiska förl. |location=Malmö |id={{LIBRIS|1335380}}}} The money for the coup had to be smuggled out from the Grill House in Stockholm, to the Royal castle in double bottom, wooden troughs filled with mortar. == Anthoni Grill (III) == '''Anthoni Grill''' (19 April 1705{{snd}}22 March 1783) was the twin brother to Claes (I), he was married to Alida Jacoba Hilke with whom he had four children. He lived in Amsterdam where he, and his brother Johannes, owned the Antoni Grill & Sons Trading House. In 1773, he became owner of the Garphyttan factories when the previous owner failed to repay the money he had borrowed from Anthoni (III). To be able to manage the factories, Anthoni (III), and his family, moved to Stockholm where he lived until his death in 1783. == Claes Grill (I) == [[File:Claes Grill Svenska industriens män.jpg|thumb|Claes Grill (I). This lithograph is mirrored since Claes Grill is always depicted with his left profile. The other side of his face was scarred and he was one-eyed.]] '''Claes Grill''' (19 April 1705{{snd}}6 November 1767) was a Swedish merchant and factory owner. Claes was the son of Abraham (I) Grill and Helena Wittmark and twin brother to Anthoni Grill. Claes married his uncle's daughter, Anna Johanna (I) Grill (1720–1778), a woman famed for her beauty. They had two children, a daughter named Anna Johanna (II) 1745–1801) and Adolf Ulric.{{cite book|last1=Grill|first1=Johan Wilhelm|last2=Grillo Ankarswärd|first2=Karl|title=Conceptbok till Grillska släktens historia|trans-title=The Grill family history|url=http://grilliana.files.wordpress.com/2009/10/jw-grills-kronika1.pdf|date=1951|location=Godegård|publisher=Mårten Persson|language=Swedish|accessdate=20 August 2014}} === Early years === Claes started to work for his father and at the age of 17 when he was employed at Abrahams office in the Grill Trading House. After the death of Abraham (I), Claes became director of the Trading House, and ran the company together with his uncle Carlos. The name of the company was changed to ''Carlos & Claes Grill'', at that time one of the largest trading company in Sweden. After the death of Carlos in 1736, he was sole head of the firm until 1747, when his half-brother joined him as partner.{{cite encyclopedia |title=Grill, Klas |editor-first=Herman |editor-last=Hofberg |encyclopedia=[[Svenskt biografiskt handlexikon]] |year=1906 |publisher=Svenskt biografiskt handlexikon via [[Project Runeberg]] | url=http://runeberg.org/sbh/a0402.html |volume=1 |pages=402–403 |language=Swedish |location=Stockholm |accessdate=20 August 2014 }} Since the family had connections to the [[Netherlands]], Claes went there in 1731 or 1732, to further his education and gain more experience with the trading business.{{cite encyclopedia |last1=Hildebrand |first1=Bengt|last2=Högberg|first2=Staffan|title =Claes Grill| encyclopedia =[[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon]] | year =1967–1969 |publisher =[[National Archives of Sweden]] |location =Stockholm |language=Swedish |volume=17 |page=281 |url =http://sok.riksarkivet.se/SBL/Presentation.aspx?id=13196 |accessdate=21 September 2014}} === The Grill Trading House === During the mid 18th century, the Grill Trading House flourished both in Sweden and abroad. They were connected to hundreds of trading houses in Europe. Foremost was the export of goods to [[Hamburg]], Amsterdam and England. The Dutch Grill company, Antoni Grill & Sons based in Amsterdam acted as a centre for payments to the Grill trading house in Stockholm. The Anglo-Swedish company run by Andrew & Charles Lindegren in London handled all the exports, shipping documents, vessel clearances, and insurance for the Grill Trading House. They also supplied Swedish ships with transit cargoes from England to the countries around the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. During the second charter of the SOIC between 1746 and 1766, the Grill Trading House was one of the leading companies in the East India trade. They were partners in a large linen and rigging factory as well as a glass factory in Stockholm. They leased the Stora Stads wharf in Stockholm, owned the Terra Nova wharf and had interests in the Djurgården wharf. All three wharfs built ships for both the SOIC and foreign customers.{{sfn|Kjellberg|1975|p=131}} The Grill Trading House also ran a banking business for Swedes traveling abroad. Since the company was connected to so many other trading houses, they could issue [[Negotiable instrument|bills of exchange]] for travelers and diplomats to be redeemed at trading houses in other countries. Under the direction of Claes, the trading house acquired several factories and ironworks: Söderfors 1748, Österbybruk with the [[Dannemora mine]] (1750) and [[Iggesund, Hudiksvall|Iggesund]] (1753). The main exports from these factories were iron, copper, [[lumber]] and [[tar]]. Imports consisted of salt from [[Portugal]], oak and [[hemp]] from the [[Baltic states]], also wine, coffee, sugar, cheese, tobacco and textiles. Claes ran his companies in an old-fashioned, patriarchal way writing letters every week to his managers at the estates concerning everything from the running of the factories to making enquiries about individual employees. Overall, the Grills industrial companies employed more than 4,000 persons at that time. === Houses and estates === [[File:Svindersvik 2009h.jpg|thumb|Svindersvik, interior]] With the building of the manor in Österbybruk, it became the hub for all the iron and mining activities of the Grill Trading House, although Claes and his family did not live there permanently. They lived in the Grill house in Stockholm until 1764, when he bought the Torstensonska Palace (now known as the [[Arvfurstens palats]]) at [[Gustav Adolfs torg, Stockholm]]. The summers were spent at [[Svindersvik]], a country residence outside Stockholm, built by Claes in the early 1740s. Claes was an art collector and his houses were decorated with [[Chinese art|Chinese]] objects as well as paintings by Swedish and Dutch masters like [[Alexander Roslin]], [[Gustaf Lundberg]], [[Hans Memling]] and [[David Teniers the Younger|David Teniers]]. He owned six complete sets of [[porcelain]] tableware commissioned from Canton. {{As of|2014}}, the oldest and largest of these still has 325 pieces preserved. Imported porcelain broken in transit from [[Qing dynasty|China]] or by daily household use became decorative gravel used on the garden paths at one of the Grills' estates. This example of wasting money and resources was condemned by those who opposed the activities of the SOIC. Even noted botanist [[Carl Linnaeus]] was at first an opponent. He wrote: "A part of the silver, which withstands the wear and tear of time and which even fire cannot destroy, we exchange for fragile objects of clay, which, once dropped, cannot be mended."{{cite book|last1=Roth|first1=Stig|title=Chinese porcelain: imported by the Swedish East India Company|date=1965|publisher=Historiska Museet|location=Göteborg|page=24|id={{LIBRIS|1520976}}}} === Benefactor === Claes was interested in [[natural science]] and contributed to different projects, such as helping Carl Linnaeus financially and with the collection of plants and animal specimens from foreign lands. In 1740, he became a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]]. He gave financial support to young scientists and naturalists, lent money (without interest) to the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for the construction of an observatory, contributed a substantial sum of money to the [[Danviken Hospital]] and saved the [[Sveriges Riksbank]] (the [[central bank]] of Sweden) from bankruptcy in 1747 by buying banknotes at their nominal value. In 1748, he became ''[[Praeses|preses]]'' or president of the Royal Academy of Sciences and was elected to the board of directors at the central bank of Sweden, a position he held until 1756.{{efn|In his speech at the Academy on 4{{nbsp}}February 1749, Claes (I) spoke on the use of shipping. In his speech he summed up the ships owned by shipping companies in Stockholm in 1749: "Ships made of oak: 62 ships up to and including 100 ''lästs'', 16 ships up to 200 ''lästs'', 4 ships up to 300 ''lästs''. Ships made of pine: 63 ships up to and including 100 ''lästs'', 31 ships up to 200 ''lästs'', 13 ships up to 300 ''lästs'' and 3 over 300 ''lästs''." {{sfn|Zethelius|1956|p=96}}}} Claes was also awarded the honorary title of ''kommerseråd'' ("trade counselor") by [[Adolf Frederick, King of Sweden|King Adolf Frederick]]. In 1755, he was one of the initiating founders of the Factory Academy, a social network for factory owners in central Sweden. === Political life and fall === Between 1748 and 1750, Claes was a member of the [[Bourgeoisie]] in the [[Riksdag of the Estates]] and politically involved with the [[Hats (party)|Hats]]. He was also one of the partners in the infamous ''Växelkontoret'' (Exchange office), a private financial institution handling mainly [[promissory note]]s without the involvement of the central bank. When the [[Caps (party)|Caps]] became the ruling party in 1765, Claes, along with his half-brother Johan Abraham and all the other members of the ''Växelkontoret'', were accused of corruption and mishandling its affairs. In 1765, Claes and Johan Abraham, were fined by the Justice deputation of the Riksdag, and in 1766, they were sentenced to pay back "five barrels of gold" to the ''Växelkontoret''. When the Hats regained their political power in the Riksdag the following year, the sentence was revoked, but by then Claes had died. == Jean Abraham Grill == {{Main|Jean Abraham Grill}} [[File:Jean Abraham Grill.jpg|thumb|Jean (Johan) Abraham Grill]] '''Jean Abraham Grill''' (21{{nbsp}}July 1736{{snd}}12{{nbsp}}March 1792), sometimes called '''Johan Abraham Grill''', was a Swedish merchant, [[supercargo]] and director of the SOIC as well as an [[ironmaster]]. Jean Abraham was the oldest son of merchant Abraham (II), and Anna Maria Petersen.{{cite encyclopedia |last=Högberg |first=Staffan|title =Johan Abraham Grill | encyclopedia =[[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon]] | year =1967–1969 |publisher =[[National Archives of Sweden]] |location =Stockholm |language=Swedish |volume=17 |page=285 |url =http://sok.riksarkivet.se/SBL/Presentation.aspx?id=13200|accessdate=23 September 2014}} He journeyed to China twice, was shipwrecked the second time,{{sfn|Kjellberg|1975|p=179}} and lived in Canton as well as [[Macau|Macao]] for almost ten years. He was the representative in Canton for the SOIC, buying goods for the company during the arrival of three ships, plus the shipwrecked ''Fredric Adolph''.{{sfn|Lindqvist|2002|p=100}} He also had two trading companies, one together with Michael Grubb,{{cite encyclopedia |title =Grubb, släkt|trans-title=Grubb, family| encyclopedia =[[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon]] | year =1967–1969 |publisher =[[National Archives of Sweden]] |location =Stockholm |language=Swedish |volume=17 |page=341 |url =http://sok.riksarkivet.se/SBL/Presentation.aspx?id=13237 |accessdate=24 September 2014}} trading with the countries close to China, and one of his own, which he used for trading tea and [[History of opium in China|smuggling opium]] from [[India]] to China.{{sfn|Kjellberg|1975|p=111}} When he returned to Sweden, he bought the Godegård ironworks and manor, along with several other ironworks, that he renovated and improved.{{sfn|Frängsmyr|1990|p=104}} All his notes, correspondence, accounts, cargo lists and books are preserved in the Godegård Archive. == Claes Grill (II) == [[File:Pass for Claes Grill and Son 1809.jpg|thumb|upright|English pass for Swedish the trading house Claes Grill & Son, and his ships to operate in certain ports in Britain, 1809]] '''Claes Grill''' (2 September 1750{{snd}}2 August 1816) was a Swedish merchant. He was the son of Abraham Grill (II) the Younger. In 1770, he settled down in London, where he met and married Maria Hackson. They had three children. In 1770, Claes became partner in the Anglo-Swedish company Andrew & Charles Lindegren, a London-based importer of Swedish iron. Andrew & Charles Lindegren traded with the Carlos & Claes Grill (the Grill Trading House) and was the major supplier of iron to the British [[East India Company]].{{cite book|last=Müller|first=Leos|editor1-last=Dickson|editor1-first=David|editor2-last=Parmentier|editor2-first=Jan|editor-last3=Ohlmeyer|editor3-first=Jane H|title=Irish and Scottish mercantile networks in Europe and overseas in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries|date=2007|publisher=Academia Press|location=Gent|isbn=90-382-1022-1|page=162|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IplIv0Z7NNAC&pg=PT174&lpg=PT174&dq=%22Andrew+%26+Charles+Lindegren%22}} The name of the company was changed first to Lindegren & Grill, and later to Lindegren son & Grill. By that name, the company continued to serve as an agent for the East India Company in [[Portsmouth]]. Claes became Counsel General to London in 1786 to 1815, Both he and [[William Chalmers (merchant)|William Chalmers]] applied for that position, but Claes was better known in the London society, had lived longer in England and was connected to a large trading house. By the time he died in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]] in 1816, Claes was also partners with a merchant, Harrison, in London.{{cite book|last1=Samuelsson|first1=Kurt|title=De stora köpmanshusen i Stockholm 1730–1815: en studie i den svenska handelskapitalismens historia|trans-title=The grand trading houses in Stockholm 1730–1815: a study in the history of Swedish trade capitalism|date=1951|publisher=Ekonomisk-historiska institutet i Stockholm|location=Stockholm|pages=46–50|id={{LIBRIS|8074825}}|language=Swedish}} == Jacob Grill == '''Jacob Grill''' (1734{{snd}}1799) was a Swedish ironworks owner. He was born in Amsterdam, the son of Anthoni Grill (III). He never married and had no children. Jacob moved to Sweden with his father and his brothers when his father became owner of the Garphyttan ironworks. In 1769, Jacob became the owner of the Skebo and Ortala ironworks, the Norrtälje gun factory and the Männäis blast furnace in [[Polyany, Leningrad Oblast|Nykyrka]], [[Turku|Åbo]], when the previous owner was forced to sell due to financial difficulties.{{cite book|last1=Norrby|first1=Jonas|title=''Jennings''|date=1991|publisher=Statens vattenfallverk|location=Vällingby|isbn=91-7186-288-9|id={{LIBRIS|7617104}}|language=Swedish}} During his time at Skebo, Jacob built the Skebo Manor in 1767 to 1770. He was very inexperienced in how to operate the ironworks, and they gradually became the property of his lender, the Tottie & Arfwedson Trading House, and in 1782, the transfer was complete. Jacob moved to Broby, then Graneberg and finally to [[Nyköping]] where he died penniless. == Adolf Ulric Grill == [[File:Bergslagssafari Uppland 2012 13 Grillska huset Söderfors bruk.jpg|thumb|The house built for the zoological collection, the Grill House, in Söderfors]] '''Adolf (Adolph) Ulric Grill''' (19 March 1752{{snd}}1 October 1797) was a Swedish ironworks owner and scientific collector of animals and [[fossil]]s for his [[cabinet of curiosities]] at [[Söderfors]]. He married his cousin, Anna Johanna (III) (1753–1809) in Stockholm on 7{{nbsp}}June 1778, they had one son who died at an early age. At the time of his marriage, Adolf Ulric lived in the Grill house in Stockholm. He and his wife moved to Söderfors when he inherited the ironworks and manor from his father Claes (I) in 1767.{{cite encyclopedia |last=Sjöberg|first=Sven|title =Adolph Ulric Grill| encyclopedia =[[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon]] |year =1967–1969|publisher =[[National Archives of Sweden]] |location =Stockholm |language=Swedish |volume=17 |page=288 |url =http://sok.riksarkivet.se/SBL/Presentation.aspx?id=13193}} === Ironworks owner === Adolf Ulric was a dedicated and hands-on owner of the ironworks at Söderfors, who supervised the operation and managed the books. Initially the factory's main products were anchors but with additions and improvements to the facilities he expanded into the production of wrought and pig iron amongst other goods. The products from the ironworks were of good quality and production peaked in 1780. === Collector === [[File:Uppstoppad häst. Hertig Fredrik Adolf - Livrustkammaren - 86954.tif|thumb|upright|Mounted horse from the Grill collection at Söderfors, now in the ''[[Livrustkammaren]]'']] Like his father, he was a [[Natural science|natural scientist]] and he collected [[Taxidermy|mounted animals]], fossils, [[mineral]]s and plants in a museum, started in 1783, at the Söderfors manor. The first specimens were collected in the vicinity of Söderfors. After two years Adolf Ulric moved on to the birds of the archipelago. He was able to use his connections through his relatives in the trading houses, to send for specimens from [[Greenland]] and [[Qing dynasty|China]]. The collections were also increased during his travels and on a journey to England in 1788, he traded a mounted [[moose]] for 60 rare birds. In 1786, Adolf Ulric built a separate house at the manor for the [[Zoology|zoological]] collection. At that time it contained 116 mounted [[mammal]]s, 600 birds, 700 [[seashell]]s and 39 fishes. The collection was displayed as a full size [[diorama]], the centerpiece being a cliff with mounted [[lion]]s, [[tiger]]s with cubs, [[leopard]]s and a number of other animals surrounding the cliff, the largest being a [[sirenia]]. The museum was the largest collection in the [[Nordic countries]] at that time, it also received some international recognition. In 1793, Adolf Ulric became a member, and ''preses'' in 1795, of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for his work with the museum. In 1828, the collection was donated to the Academy by the Grill family. As a tribute to him, the [[giant oarfish]] (''Gymnetrus Grillii''),{{efn|The name was given in 1798, and has since been altered to ''Regalecus glesne''.{{cite web|last1=Froese|first1=Rainer|title=Synonyms of Regalecus glesne Ascanius, 1772|url=http://www.fishbase.org/Nomenclature/SynonymsList.php?ID=3267&SynCode=30575&GenusName=Regalecus&SpeciesName=glesne|website=www.fishbase.org|publisher=FishBase|accessdate=19 September 2014}}}} was named after him. === Builder === Adolf Ulric paid for the building of a church in Söderfors that was inaugurated on 30{{nbsp}}September 1792. Three years later, at a time of crop failure and famine in Söderfors, he started the construction of an English garden at the manor to provide jobs for the farmers in Söderfors and the neighboring [[Hedesunda]] ''[[socken]]''. As a result, the park, a main feature in Söderfors, is sometimes called the ''Hedesunda brödkaka'' (the Hedesunda bread biscuit). Since 1998, the park has been included in the listed buildings of Söderfors. Adolf Ulric was known as a music lover and amateur composer. Wherever he lived, he organized well attended concert nights, with musicians invited from Stockholm. In 1772, he became a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Music.{{cite book|last1=Nyström|first1=Pia|last2=Kyhlberg-Boström|first2=Anna|last3=Elmquist|first3=Anne-Marie|title=Kungl. Musikaliska akademien: matrikel 1771–1995|trans-title=The Royal Swedish Academy of Music: members 1771–1995|date=1996|publisher=[[Royal Swedish Academy of Music]]|location=Stockholm|isbn=91-85428-99-X|series=Kungl. Musikaliska akademiens skriftserie, 0347-5158 ; 84|edition=2., rev. och utök. uppl.|id={{LIBRIS|7749167}}|language=Swedish}} == Estates, mansions and factories == These are some of the estates and factories owned by members of the Grill family or by the Grill Trading House during the 18th and 19th century. == The Grill house, Stockholm == [[File:Grillska huset.jpg|thumb|upright|120px|The Grill house in Gamla stan, Stockholm]] The Grill House at Stortorget 3 in [[Gamla stan]], Stockholm was built during the Middle Ages and thoroughly converted in 1649. Although subsequently remodeled in 1750 and 1914, the large molded [[baroque]] [[gable]] and some of the painted joists date to the 17th century conversion. The classic [[lesene]] of the facade and some of the interior are from the mid 18th century. It acquired its name in the 17th century when the house was purchased by Anthoni Grill (II). The Grill family owned the house for more than two hundred years and {{As of|2013|lc=y}}, it houses the ''Stockholms Stadsmission'' (The Stockholm City Mission).{{cite web|last1=Persson|first1=Mårten|title=Några av släkten Grills gods och gårdar.|trans-title=Some of the Grill's houses and manors.|url=http://grilliana.files.wordpress.com/2009/10/gods-o-gc3a5rdar-3.pdf|website=www.grilliana.files.wordpress.com|publisher=The Grill family|accessdate=27 July 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Gledin|first1=Ewa|title=Om Grillska Huset|trans-title=About the Grill house|url=http://www.stadsmissionen.se/Matochkonferens/Grillska-Huset/|website=www.stadsmissionen.se|publisher=Stockholms Stadsmission|accessdate=27 July 2014}} == The Grill mansion, Uppsala == [[File:40C42GM2VF59EKTO 773.jpeg|thumb|120px|left|The Grill manor, Uppsala]] The Grill family (possibly Claes Grill (I)) started to build the Grill manor in central [[Uppsala]] after the great fire in 1766. At the time, the family owned ironworks at [[Söderfors]] and Österby in [[Uppland]], as well as at Iggesund in [[Hälsingland]]. The estate was completed in 1770. The Grill family owned the manor until 1790. It is the only preserved town manor in Uppsala. {{As of|2013}}, it houses apartments and offices for the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red cross]] and [[Save the Children]].{{cite web|title=Kakelugn från 1700-talet i Grillska garden.|trans-title=A tiled stove from the 1700s in the Grill manor.|url=http://www.digitaltmuseum.se/things/kakelugn-frn-1700-talet-i-grillska-grden/S-UM/DIA00283|website=www.digitaltmuseum.se|publisher=Digitalt Museum—Upplandsmuseet|accessdate=27 July 2014}}{{cite journal|last1=Ehn|first1=Ola|title=Grillska gården i Uppsala|trans-title=The Grill manor in Uppsala|publisher=Upplandsmuseet|location=Uppsala|date=1984|url=http://www.uppsalasmuseer.se/umi_upplandsmuseet.html|accessdate=27 July 2014}} {{clear}} == The Lennart Torstensons palace == [[File:Arvfurstens palats september 2011.jpg|thumb|120px|The Arvfurstens Palace, Stockholm]] {{Main|Arvfurstens palats}} Claes Grill (I) bought the palace in 1764, and lived there until he died in 1767, after which it was passed on to his wife Anna Johanna (I), and later their daughter Anna Johanna (II). In 1783, it was bought by Princess [[Sophia Albertina, Abbess of Quedlinburg|Sophia Albertina]] and converted into a part of the [[Arvfurstens palats]].{{cite book|last1=Ellehag|first1=Claes|title=Palatsen i Stockholm under stormaktstiden|trans-title=The Palaces in Stockholm during the Swedish Empire|date=1998|publisher=Signum|location=Lund|isbn=91-87896-38-9|pages=126–128|series=Böcker om konst (Signum), 99-0345976-9|id={{LIBRIS|7767599}}|language=Swedish}} {{As of|1906}} it houses the Swedish [[Ministry for Foreign Affairs (Sweden)|Ministry for Foreign Affairs]].{{cite web|title=Arvfurstens palats|url=http://www.sfv.se/sv/fastigheter/sverige/stockholms-lan-ab/regeringskvarteren/kvarteret_lejonet/arvfurstens-palats/|website=www.sfv.se|publisher=Statens Fastighetsverk|accessdate=10 August 2014}} == Svindersvik == {{Main|Svindersvik}} [[File:Svindersvik 2009.jpg|thumb|120px|left|Svindersvik in Nacka]] Built by Claes Grill (I), the residence was designed by architect Carl Hårleman in the early 1740s. It is one of Sweden's oldest preserved country residences. Claes and his wife Anna Johanna (I), would live in Stockholm during the winter and spend the summers at Svindersvik. The residence was usually accessed by rowboat. The style of the residence is rococo, with many Chinese elements brought to Sweden by the SOIC. At the death of Claes (I), the estate was passed on to his daughter Anna Johanna (II). The house was sold in 1780, and passed through several owners, until it was bought by silk manufacturer K.A. Almgren in 1863. {{As of|1949}}, the house is owned by the Nordic Museum.{{cite web|title=A rococo style country residence|url=http://www.nordiskamuseet.se/node/2313|website=www.nordiskamuseet.se|publisher=[[Nordic Museum]]|accessdate=10 August 2014}} {{clear}} == Söderfors == [[File:Bergslagssafari Uppland 2012 13 Söderfors herrgård 1.jpg|thumb|120px|The Söderfors manor, main building]] [[File:Söderfors Elias Martin.jpg|thumb|120px|Söderfors ironworks, c. 1800 by [[Elias Martin]]]] The Grill's estate in Söderfors largely made up the entire town at that time along with the ironworks and the manor. The ironworks were founded in 1676 to make anchors. Claes Grill (I) bought the ironworks in 1748, and it stayed within the Grill family until 1907.{{cite book|editor=Fritz Martin|title=Söderfors 300 år|date=1976|publisher=Stora Kopparbergs bergslags AB|location=Falun|pages=37–49|id={{LIBRIS|129674}}|language=Swedish|ref=Soderfors}} The factory passed through several owners and is, since 1995, owned and operated by Scana Steel Söderfors AB, a company with production in Norway, Sweden and China.{{cite web|title=Scana Steel Söderfors|url=http://www.scana.no/en/companies/scana-steel-soederfors|website=www.scana.no|publisher=Scana|accessdate=10 August 2014}} The first manor was finished in 1700 then between 1749 and 1756 it was rebuilt by architect Carl Hårleman for Claes Grill (I). After his death, the manor passed to his son Adolf Ulric. He was an avid [[Natural history|naturalist]] and during his redidence he filled it with art and specimens of mounted animals, minerals, fossils and plants. Adolph Ulric had a separate house built for his collection in 1786. He also started the construction of an English garden at Söderfors by the river [[Dalälven]]. Gustaf af Sillén completed the park, which is one of the main features in Söderfors.{{cite web|title=Engelska parken i Söderfors bruk.|trans-title=The English garden at Söderfors.|url=http://www.lansstyrelsen.se/uppsala/Sv/samhallsplanering-och-kulturmiljo/skyddad-bebyggelse/byggnadsminnen/byggnadsminnen-i-uppsala-lan/engelska-parken-i-soderfors/Pages/default.aspx|website=www.lansstyrelsen.se|publisher=Länsstyrelsen Uppsala län|accessdate=10 August 2014}} {{As of|2014}}, the manor is a hotel and conference venue. On 20{{nbsp}}December 1985, most of the ironworks and the surrounding area of Söderfors, a total of 91 buildings, became [[Listed buildings in Sweden|listed buildings]], making it one of the largest listed sites in Sweden.{{cite web|title=Tierp Söderfors bruk|url=http://www.bebyggelseregistret.raa.se/bbr2/sok/resultatLista.raa?type=BYG&open=inv:0:undefined|website=www.bebyggelseregistret.raa.se|publisher=[[Swedish National Heritage Board]]|accessdate=10 August 2014}} {{cite web|title=Welcome to Söderfors Herrgård|url=http://www.soderforsherrgard.se/|website=www.soderforsherrgard.se|publisher=Söderfors Herrgård|accessdate=10 August 2014}} == Österbybruk == [[File:Österbybruks herrgård.jpg|thumb|120px|left|The Österbybruks mansion, main building]] [[File:The double bullet stamp.jpg|thumb|100px|left|The "Double Bullet" stamp]] The ironworks at Österbybruk were established by King [[Gustav I of Sweden]] with the help of German experts during the 16th century and specialised in making munitions. During the 17th century the factories were merged with Lövsta and Gimo, under the directions of [[Louis De Geer (1587–1652)|Louis De Geer]], making it the second largest ironworks in Sweden.{{cite book|last1=Dahlgren|first1=Erik Wilhelm|title=De uppländska bruken Österby, Forsmark, Leufsta och Gimo under äldsta tider|trans-title=The Upplandic ironworks Österby, Forsmark, Leufsta and Gimo during the elder days|date=1928|location=Stockholm|id={{LIBRIS|1488887}}|language=Swedish}} Since De Geer recruited skilled iron workers from the [[Wallonia|Walloon Region]] of Belgium, these ironworks became known as the Walloon factories ("Wallonbruken"). The iron ore processed in Österby came from the Dannemora mine and was noted for its purity. Iron bars produced at these ironworks were stamped with a "Double Bullet" mark, which guaranteed high and consistent quality. Such iron became reputable in England, where it was used by the steel industry in [[Sheffield]]. In 1758, the ironworks was sold to the Grill Trading house, at that time owned by Claes (I) and Johan Abraham. The trading house was discontinued with the death of Johan Abraham in 1799, and the ironworks was sold to Anna Johanna (III), the wife of Adolf Ulric.{{cite book|last1=Tham|first1=Wilhelm|title=Beskrifning öfver Sveriges rike. Bd 1. H. 3, Beskrifning öfver Upsala län|trans-title=Description of the land of Sweden. Description of Upsala county|date=1850|publisher=C. A. Bagge|location=Stockholm|id={{LIBRIS|387888}}|language=Swedish}} The factory passed through several owners until it was closed in 1983.{{cite web|title=Österbybruk|url=http://www.svetur.se/sv/osthammar/products/105349/Osterbybruk/|website=www.svetur.se|publisher=Visit Roslagen|accessdate=20 August 2014}} In 1763, Claes (I) started construction of the mansion at Österbybruk. The mansion incorporated the two wings already built in the 1730s; the west wing which served as housing for one of the ironworks caretakers and the east wing containing a chapel. The mansion was not completed until 1780, due to the decline of the East India trade, accusations of financial misconduct against Claes and Johan Abraham and the [[Amsterdam Banking Crisis of 1763|banking crises in Amsterdam in 1763]].{{cite encyclopedia |last=Hildebrand|first=Bengt|title=Claes Grill |encyclopedia=[[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon]] |year=1967–1969|volume=17|page=281|publisher=[[National Archives of Sweden]] |location=Stockholm |url=http://sok.riksarkivet.se/SBL/Presentation.aspx?id=13196|language=Swedish }} {{As of|2014}}, the manor is owned by the [[Bruno Liljefors]] Foundation. His studio in one of the buildings is preserved and is on occasion open to the public.{{cite web|last1=Högström|first1=Leif|title=Österbybruk|url=http://web.vallonbruken.nu/dokumentarkiv/historiska_kartor/osterbybruk.pdf|website=www.vallonbruken.nu|publisher=Vallonbruk i Uppland med Länsstyrelsen i Uppsala län|accessdate=20 August 2014}} {{clear}} == Iggesunds bruk == [[File:Iggesunds bruk.JPG|thumb|120px|The 19th-century blast furnaces at the Iggesunds bruk]] The ironworks at Iggesund is predated by a sawmill established by the Swedish state in 1572. The first ironworks were established in 1685, by the trader Isak Breant, the Elder. It included a blast furnace, a forge with a [[trip hammer]] and two [[finery forge]]s. The iron ore came from [[Utö, Sweden|Utö]] and the [[Dannemora mine]]. After the [[Tsardom of Russia|Russians]] burned Iggesund down [[Great Northern War#1719–1721: Sweden|during raids along the Swedish coastline]] in 1721, the ironworks was bought by the Grill Trading House. The Grills successfully ran and improved the factories during most of the 18th century.{{cite web|title=Hudiksvalls bruksminnen|url=http://www.bruksminnen.com/|website=www.bruksminnen.com|publisher=The Hudiksvalls Bruksminnen Foundation|accessdate=24 August 2014}} With the decline of the Trading House in 1800, the ironworks went through several owners until it was sold to the owners of Österbybruk at that time. During the 20th century the ironworks were, through several owners, transformed and diversified into a sawmill, pulp and paper industry, chemical plant, dairy and agricultural companies. {{As of|1988}}, Iggesunds bruk is a part of [[Iggesund Paperboard]].{{cite web|last1=Klingström|first1=Lars|title=Holmen 400 år, 1609–2009|url=https://www.holmen.com/sv/Om-Holmen/Holmen-400-ar/Tidslinje/|website=www.holmen.com|publisher=Holmen|accessdate=24 August 2014}} == Godegård == [[File:Godegårds herrgård närbild 2005-07-08.jpg|thumb|120px|left|The Godegård manor]] [[File:Timmerspik.jpg|thumb|120px|left|Hand wrought iron nail for the ship ''[[Götheborg (ship)|Götheborg III]]'']] The Grill's estates at the village of Godegård, the manor and the ironworks, dominated the community during the 18th century. Mining had been done in the area as early as in the [[Middle Ages]], and by the early 17th century, an ironworks was already established at Godegård. The ironworks was bought by Louis De Geer in 1618. He improved and expanded the factories and recruited skilled [[Walloons]] iron workers to teach the Swedes how to use a finery forge.{{cite web|last1=Ekinge|first1=Robert|title=Louis De Geer|url=http://www.ekinge.nu/orterna/godegard/main.htm|website=www.ekinge.nu|publisher=Robert Ekinge|accessdate=24 August 2014}} When he died, the ironworks and the first manor passed on to his son Jean De Geer. After a fire in 1719, the new manor was built. It was completed in 1725.{{cite encyclopedia |title=Godegård |encyclopedia=[[Nordisk familjebok]] |year=1800|publisher=[[Project Runeberg]] |location=Stockholm|volume=5|pages=1333–4|url=http://runeberg.org/nfae/0673.html|language=Swedish }} Settling down in Sweden after his profitable journeys to China, [[Jean Abraham Grill|Jean Abraham]] was looking for something to invest in. He started negotiations for the purchase of land, manor and factory at Godegård, at that time the largest ironworks in [[Östergötland]], and bought them all in 1775. Jean Abraham continued the expansion of the ironworks and made significant restoration of the manor. He also built an English garden, designed by [[Fredrik Magnus Piper]], with several gazebos in a Chinese style. The ironworks was closed in 1896, but the manor remained in the Grill family until 1980. It became a listed building in 1977.{{cite web|title=Godegårds säteri|url=http://www.bebyggelseregistret.raa.se/bbr2/anlaggning/visaHelaHistoriken.raa;jsessionid=69A925E45E7B732CC72CC6B3338C42B1.lx-ra-bbr?anlaggningId=21300000008136&historikId=21000000523442|website=www.bebyggelseregistret.raa.se|publisher=Swedish National Heritage Board|accessdate=25 August 2014}} Jean Abraham collected all of his letters, accounts and notes in an archive at Godegård, now known as the Godegård Archive. {{As of|2003}}, the archive, containing over 7,000 document, is in the [[Nordic Museum]]. It has been digitized and is available on line as result of a request from the Macau Historical Archives in 2003.{{cite web|last1=Gram|first1=Magdalena|title=Svenska Ostindiska Kompaniet|trans-title=Swedish East India CompanyI|url=http://ostindiska.nordiskamuseet.se/|website=ostindiska.nordiskamuseet.se|publisher=[[Nordic Museum]]|accessdate=25 August 2014}} {{clear}} == Mariedamm == [[File:Trehörnings masugn, Mariedamm.jpg|thumb|120px|The Trehörnings blast furnace]] The Trehörnings blast furnace in Mariedamm was originally built by local miners in 1636. Louis De Geer bought it in 1648, and it became part of the Godegårds ironworks which was sold on to Jean Abraham in 1775. The blast furnace remained a part of the Grill's estate at Godegård until 1888, when it was sold to the [[Skyllbergs bruk]]. The blast furnace was in operation until 1889. Since 1923, it is in being cared for and renovated by the Lerbäck Heritage society.{{cite web|title=Trehörnings masugn|trans-title=The Trehörnings blast furnace|url=http://www.lansstyrelsen.se/orebro/Sv/samhallsplanering-och-kulturmiljo/byggnadsvard/kulturmiljo/sevarda-kulturmiljoer/askersund/trehornings-masugn/Pages/index.aspx|website=www.lansstyrelsen.se|publisher=Länsstyrelsen Örebro län|accessdate=26 August 2014}} At the beginning of the 19th century, a mansion was built in Mariedamm by the Grill family. The mansion was demolished in the 1920s, only one of the wings remain.{{cite journal|last1=Persson|first1=Mårten|title=Andreas Gustaf Grill – bergsman och entreprenör|trans-title=Andreas Gustaf Grill – miner and entrepreneur |journal=D-dissertation at the history dep. of the Lund university.|date=2007}} == Garphyttan == [[File:Garphytte bruk.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Administration building at Garphyttan.]] The mining at Garphyttan was started during the Middle Ages by German miners. These were called "garps", a medieval Swedish word meaning "loudmouths" or "braggers".{{cite encyclopedia |title=Garp |encyclopedia=[[Nordisk familjebok]] |year=1908|publisher=[[Project Runeberg]] |location=Stockholm|volume=9|pages=764–4|url=http://runeberg.org/nfbi/0400.html|language=Swedish }} The main product was lead ore which also contained silver, but the yield from the ore was small and business faltered a number of times during the 17th century and early 18th century. It was not until the factory was bought by three Dutch merchants in 1661, that the company started to flourish again. A trip hammer, two hearths, a smithy, a saw mill, a silver refinery and housing for the workers were added. The factories and the ironworks went through several owners until 1773, when Abraham (III) acquired them all. The previous owner had borrowed money from the Anthony Grill & Sons Trading House in Amsterdam, and when he failed to repay the loan, the factories became the property of the Grills. The building of a manor at Garphyttan started during the 17th century, and several additions were made in the middle of the 18th century. The main building of the manor was destroyed during a fire in 1830, only the four wings remain.{{cite book|last1=Nachmanson|first1=August|last2=Hannerberg|first2=David|title=Garphyttan: ett gammalt bruks historia|trans-title=Garphyttan: the history of an old orinworks|date=1945|publisher=Bonnier|location=Stockholm|id={{LIBRIS|26310}}|language=Swedish}} {{clear}} == Stora Nyckelviken == [[File:Nyckelviken herrgård 2011.jpg|thumb|120px|The Nyckelviken manor, main building]] Stora Nyckelviken manor was completed in 1746 by Herman Petersen, a wealthy merchant and director of the SOIC. The manor was designed in much the same style as the other manors built with the profits from the East India trade. It consists of a main building, wings, gazebos and a park. The manor was only owned by the Grill family for a short period of time. Jean Abraham Grill bought it in 1760, and sold it 20 years later. {{As of|2014}} the manor is owned by the municipality of Nacka. It houses a restaurant and a conference venue.{{cite web|title=Stora Nyckelviken|url=http://www.stockholmslansmuseum.se/upptack_lanet/visa/b041/|website=www.stockholmslansmuseum.se|publisher=Stockholms läns museum|accessdate=27 August 2014}} == Skebo and Ortala == [[File:Swedish castle Skebo bruk Sweden.JPG|thumb|left|120px|The Skebo manor]] [[File:Ortala bruk.jpg|thumb|left|120px|Coal storage at the Ortala ironworks]] The first ironworks in Skebo was built in the 15th century. The iron ore was mined locally in the forests surrounding the factory. The first smithy with a trip hammer at Skebo, was constructed by Hindrich Lemmens in 1626. The iron from the ironworks was mainly sold to the Norrtälje rifle factory, which made weapons used in the [[Thirty Years' War]]. During the 18th century the Skebo and Ortala (a similar mine and factory nearby) ironworks were operated jointly. They went through several owners, due to the economical entanglements and financial difficulties of the directors and investors. One of these affairs resulted in Jacob Grill obtaining Skebo and Ortala, along with three other factories in 1769, from the previous owner who could not pay his debt to Jacob. Jacob had no experience in operating an ironworks, he got into financial difficulties and had to sell the factories in 1782. The ironworks flourished during the 19th century, and began to decline after 1900, ending in bankruptcy in 1924.{{cite web|title=Ett av Upplands äldsta järnbruk|trans-title=One of the oldest ironworks in Uppland|url=http://www.skebobruksmuseum.se/html/skebo_bruks_historia.html|website=www.skebobruksmuseum.se|publisher=Skebobruks Museum|accessdate=28 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127031212/http://skebobruksmuseum.se/html/skebo_bruks_historia.html|archivedate=27 November 2013|df=}} During his time at Skebo, Jacob built a manor in 1767–1770. During the 19th century the new owners filled it with art and sculptures and it became a center for the local socialite. When the ironworks folded the manor became a retirement home for elderly gentlemen, a spa, a house for seminars and workshops, and in 2010, a noted restaurant listed in the White Guide 2012.{{cite web|title=Detta har hänt|trans-title=The story so far|url=http://skeboherrgard.se/om_oss/historik|website=skeboherrgard.se|publisher=Skebo Herrgård|accessdate=28 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234227/http://skeboherrgard.se/om_oss/historik|archivedate=30 December 2013|df=}} {{As of|2013}}, the restaurant is closed and the manor is a temporary lodging for refugees seeking asylum in Sweden.{{cite web|last1=Andersson|first1=Ki|title=Skebo herrgård tillfällig bostad för flyktingar|trans-title=Skebo manor temporary home for refugees|url=http://norrteljetidning.se/nyheter/nyheter/1.2260799-skebo-herrgard-tillfallig-bostad-for-flyktingar|website=norrteljetidning.se|publisher=Norrtelje Tidning|accessdate=28 August 2014}} {{clear}} == The Lövåsen lead and silver factory == [[File:Sockensten Stora Skedvi 50-1.jpg|thumb|120px|Marker at Stora Skedvi]] The Lövåsen lead and silver factory in Stora Skedvi was one of the first factories to be connected with the Grill family. The Swedish government handed over the administration of the factory to Anthoni Grill (I) in 1656, to be used as a laboratory and workshop by him. He had claimed that he was in possession of a secret "matter" that would enable him to extract much more copper, lead, silver and gold from the ore than by other conventional methods. He experimented fore some years at the laboratory, but he never improved the extraction process, and was consequently demoted from his position at the mine. {{As of|2014}}, there are no visible remains of the mine or the factory. == Ersta == [[File:Ersta 2009e.jpg|thumb|120px|left|The Ersta manor]] Ersta is one of the many ''malmgårdarna'' (suburban manors) built in Stockholm during the 17th and 18th century. At these manors, wealthy, noble families from different parts of Sweden, could enjoy the same comforts as in their homes in the country. The manors were built in the suburbs, close to what constituted Stockholm in the 17th century and 18th century. The city has grown considerably since then, and these locations are now considered to be part of central Stockholm. Many of the buildings, the entire manor or part of them, are still in use and embedded in the modern cityscape.{{cite book|last1=Lindberg|first1=Birgit|title=Malmgårdarna i Stockholm|trans-title=The suburban manors of Stockholm|date=1985|publisher=LiberFörlag|location=Stockholm|isbn=91-38-90418-7|page=16|id={{LIBRIS|7268833}}}} Ersta, on the high cliffs of southern Stockholm, was probably built in the 1670s by [[brännvin]] manufacturer Oluf Håkansson. At that time the land in that area was cheap since it was close to the old gallows. When the gallows was moved further away from town to make way for a new shipyard, the Stora Stads wharf, where ships for the SOIC were built, the area around Ersta became sought after and was called "a garden". The mansion passed through several owners until Jean Abraham Grill bought it in 1755. In 1770, he established a [[crucible steel]] factory at Ersta with the help of [[Bengt Andersson Qvist]], a member of the [[Swedish Board of Mines]]. Members of the Qvist family were inspectors at the Iggesund ironworks. The steel was of good quality, but nevertheless unprofitable. In 1775, Jean Abraham sold the manor and the steel factory to Qvist who ran the company until it folded with his death in 1799.{{cite book|last1=Lindberg|first1=Birgit|title=Malmgårdarna i Stockholm|trans-title=Suburban manors of Stockholm|date=1985|publisher=LiberFörlag|location=Stockholm|isbn=91-38-90418-7|pages=45–48|id={{LIBRIS|7268833}}}} {{As of|2014}}, only two of the buildings at the manor remain. They are a part of the Ersta Hospital and one of them houses the Ersta museum.{{cite web|title=Hur staden på berget växte fram|trans-title=How the city on the mountain came to be|url=http://www.erstadiakoni.se/Erstamuseum/Staden-pa-berget/Hur-staden-pa-berget-vaxte-fram/|website=www.erstadiakoni.se|publisher=Ersta diakoni|accessdate=28 August 2014}} {{clear}} == Notes == {{notelist|30em}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === * {{cite book |last=Frängsmyr |first=Tore |title=Ostindiska kompaniet: människorna, äventyret och den ekonomiska drömmen |trans-title=The Swedish East India company: the people, the adventure and the economic dream |language=Swedish |edition=2 |date=1990 |publisher=Wiken |location=Höganäs |isbn=91-7024-653-X |id={{LIBRIS|7591876}} |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Lindqvist |first=Herman |title=Historien om ostindiefararna |trans-title=The story of the East Indiamen |language=Swedish |date=2002 |publisher=Hansson & Lundvall |location=Gothenburg |isbn=91-85023-02-7 |id={{LIBRIS|8843398}} |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Kjellberg |first=Sven T. |title=Svenska ostindiska compagnierna 1731–1813: kryddor, te, porslin, siden |trans-title=The Swedish East India company 1731–1813: spice, tea, porcelain, silk |language=Swedish |edition=2 |date=1975 |publisher=Allhem |location=Malmö |isbn=91-7004-058-3 |id={{LIBRIS|107047}} |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |last1=Zethelius |first1=Gustaf A |title=Stockholms-varven under 1700-talet. |trans-title=The wharfs of Stockholm during the 18th century. |journal=Sjöhistorisk årsbok 1955–56 |date=1956 |pages=57–102 |publisher=Sjöhistoriska museet |location=Stockholm |id={{LIBRIS|9878825}} |issn=0349-019X |ref=harv}} == Further reading == * {{cite book |last1=Ahlander |first1=Björn |last2=Langert |first2=Jens |title=Skeppsboken – livet ombord på en Ostindiefarare |trans-title=The ship's log – life aboard an East Indiaman |language=Swedish |date=2009 |publisher=Svenska ostindiska companiet |location=Göteborg |isbn=978-91-633-4889-1 |id={{LIBRIS|11607831}} }} * {{cite book |last1=Arensberg |first1=Ingrid |title=Ostindiefararen Götheborg seglar igen |trans-title=The Swedish ship Götheborg sails again |language=Swedish, English |date=2009 |publisher=Svenska ostindiska companiet |location=Göteborg |isbn=978-91-633-4846-4 |id={{LIBRIS|11614816}} }} * {{cite book |last1=Campbell |first1=Colin |last2=Hallberg |first2=Paul |last3=Koninckx |first3=Christian |title=A passage to China: Colin Campbell's diary of the first Swedish East India Company expedition to Canton, 1732–33 |series=Acta Regiae Societatis scientiarum et litterarum Gothoburgensis. Humaniora, 0072-4823 ; 37 |date=1996 |publisher=Royal Society of Arts and Sciences (Kungl. Vetenskaps- och vitterhets-samhället) |location=Gothenburg |isbn=91-85252-55-7 |id={{LIBRIS|7747182}} }} * {{cite book |last=Högberg |first=Staffan |title=Utrikeshandel och sjöfart på 1700-talet: stapelvaror i svensk export och import 1738–1808 |trans-title=Foreign trade and shipping in the 18th century: goods in Swedish export and import 1738–1808 |series=Ekonomi och samhälle, 99-0119059-2 |language=Swedish |date=1969 |publisher=Bonnier |location=Stockholm |isbn= |id={{LIBRIS|8075889}} |accessdate=25 September 2014 }} * {{cite book |last=Koninckx |first=Christian |title=The first and second charters of the Swedish East India company (1731–1766): a contribution to the maritime, economic and social history of north-western Europe in its relationships with the Far East |trans-title=|date=1980 |publisher=Van Ghemmert |location=Kortrijk |isbn= |id={{LIBRIS|218016}} |accessdate= }} == External links == {{Commons category|Grillska garden|The Grill mansion, Uppsala}} {{Commons category|Svindersvik}} {{Commons category|Söderfors bruk}} {{Commons category|Österbybruk}} *[http://grilliana.wordpress.com/ Website of the Grill family] *[http://ostindiska.nordiskamuseet.se/ The Godegårds archive at the Nordic Museum] *[http://www.ub.gu.se/samlingar/handskrift/ostindie/ The SOIC archive at the Gothenburg University Library] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030207/http://www.cbg.nl/download/grill_family.pdf The Grill Family from Sweden and the Netherlands and their Chinese Armorial Services] {{coord missing|Sweden}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grill (family)}} [[Category:Swedish families]] [[Category:Business families of Sweden]] [[Category:18th-century Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Swedish merchants]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Swedish East India Company people]] [[Category:History of foreign trade in China]] [[Category:Manor houses in Sweden]] [[Category:Ironworks in Sweden]] [[Category:Trading companies]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[vuorineuvos]] | name = Heikki Hugo Herlin | honorific_suffix = | image = Heikki-Herlin-1955.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Heikki H. Herlin in 1955. | pronunciation = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1901|2|7}} | birth_place = [[Helsinki]], [[Grand Duchy of Finland]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1989|8|21|1901|2|7}} | death_place = [[Kirkkonummi]], [[Finland]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | burial_place = | burial_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = [[Diplomi-insinööri|MSc (technology)]] | alma_mater = [[Helsinki University of Technology]] | occupation = | years_active = | era = | organization = | known_for = | home_town = | title = | term = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = see →[[#Board memberships|board memberships]] | religion = | spouse = Anna Maria [[née]] Oittinen | children = * Minna, married Paavolainen (b. 1931) * [[Pekka Herlin|Pekka]] (1932–2003) * Meeri, married Blåberg (b. 1936) * Liisa, married Kivekäs (b. 1936) | parents = [[Harald Herlin|Bror Harald Herlin]] and
Minna née Westerlund{{cite web |url=http://www.kansallisbiografia.fi/kb/artikkeli/1563/ |title=Herlin, Heikki (1901–1989) |last=Hoffman |first=Kai |date=2008-04-14 |website=Kansallisbiografia |publisher=Suomalaisen Kirjallisuuden Seura |location=Helsinki |language=Finnish |access-date=2016-03-05 |registration=yes }}{{cite web |url=http://www.kansallisbiografia.fi/talousvaikuttajat/?iid=736 |title=Vuorineuvos Heikki Herlin (1901–1989) |last=Hoffman |first=Kai |date=2008-09-05 |website=Kansallisbiografia |publisher=Suomalaisen Kirjallisuuden Seura |location=Helsinki |language=Finnish |access-date=2016-03-05 }} | relatives = | awards = see →[[#Awards|awards]] | module = {{Infobox officeholder | embed = yes | office = Manager of [[Kone]] | term_start = 1932 | term_end = 1964 | predecessor = [[Harald Herlin]] | successor = [[Pekka Herlin]] | office2 = Manager of Emali | term_start2 = 1932 | term_end2 = 1943 | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | office3 = Manager of [[Raahe (company)|Raahe]] | term_start3 = 1953 | term_end3 = 1962 | predecessor3 = | successor3 = }} | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = }} '''Heikki Hugo Herlin''' (7 February 1901 — 21 August 1989) was a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[engineer]], [[industrialist]] and [[vuorineuvos]]. Herlin gained experience by studying and working abroad, before he inherited his father's position as manager of the [[Elevator|lift]] producer [[Kone|Kone Oy]] in 1932. He developed the company substantially and started [[export]]s already in the 1930s. After Kone had participated at delivering large number of units to [[Soviet Union]] as part of the [[Finnish war reparations to the Soviet Union|Finnish war reparations]], Herlin established fruitful business relations with the Soviet Union. Herlin had broad language skills which he utilised when he developed Kone an international company. In 1964 he gave the leadership to his son [[Pekka Herlin]], continuing still as a board member. Herlin was member of many company boards as wells as non-profit associations. He founded the Kone Foundation which supports cultural and sociological research. == Early years == Herlin's parents were engineer [[Harald Herlin]] and Minna [[née]] Westerlund. Harald Herlin was a [[Water pipe|water piping]] specialist and he managed [[plumbing]] company ''Oy Vesijohtoliike Ab'' until 1920. He also worked as [[consultant]], and at the early 1920s he was assigned to [[Reorganisation|reorganise]] electromechanical company [[Strömberg (company)|Ab Gottfr. Strömberg Oy]]. Subsequently, he bought the company's [[Elevator|lift]] business in 1924. The company, [[Kone|Kone Oy]], run small-scale [[licensed production]]. == Studies and early career == Herlin studied in [[Helsingin Suomalainen Yhteiskoulu|Helsinki Finnish Coeducational School]] and passed his [[Matriculation exam (Finland)|matriculation exam]] in 1919. He went to study [[mechanical engineering]] in [[Helsinki University of Technology]] and graduated in 1924. During 1925–1926 Herlin worked for [[Brown, Boveri & Cie|AG Brown Boveri & Cie]] in [[Mannheim]], [[Weimar Republic|Germany]]. In 1926 he returned to Finland for a short time to work as draftsman for Gottfr. Strömberg, but left already in 1927 to continue his studies in [[Columbia University]], United States. At the same time he worked as [[draughtsman]] for some American engineering companies. When Herlin returned to Finland in 1928, he initially worked as a designer for Kone, his father's company. During 1929–1932 Herlin worked as technical manager in [[Kone- ja Siltarakennus]] to managing [[Separator (milk)|separator]] production. == Manager of Kone == In 1932 Herlin followed his father as manager of Kone. The production in the [[Helsinki]]-located factory had grown steadily during Harald Herlin's leadership, but now the company started to develop rapid. The [[product quality]] was improved to meet an international standard and [[productivity]] was improved. Finland was in an economical upswing after the [[1930s recession]] was overcome, and number of new buildings, equipped with Kone lifts, were constructed. Also exports started in the same time. Prior to the [[Winter War]], the company employed 300–400 people and the annual production reached 250 lifts. Herlin became an influential representative of the Finnish engineering industry during the war years. After the [[Continuation War]] between Finland and Soviet Union ended to [[Moscow Armistice]], Finland had to pay large [[Finnish war reparations to the Soviet Union|war reparations to Soviet Union]]. This included a number of Kone lifts and [[Crane (machine)|cranes]]. When the war reparations were finally paid off in the early 1950s, Herlin continued the export within normal trade agreements. At the turn of the 1960s, Kone was one of the ten biggest companies of Finland employing 2 000 people. Heikki H. Herlin led Kone until 1964 after which he was followed by his son [[Pekka Herlin]], but continued as board member until 1987. == Character == [[File:Habib-Bourguiba-1963-Finlande.jpg|240px|thumb|right|Herlin (right) presenting [[Kone]] premises to the [[President of Tunisia|Tunisian president]] [[Habib Bourguiba]] (middle) and the [[President of Finland|Finnish president]] [[Urho Kekkonen]] (left).]] Herlin's early international experience effected on his career as Kone manager. He put focus on [[product development]] and was open-minded at extending the [[market area]]. His contribution on war reparation industry was significant; he also saw the potential of the Soviet market already in the 1940s. While Herlin had strong background and expertise in engineering industry, he had broad knowledge in other areas as well. He took part in organisational activities, such as [[Rotary Club]] and voluntary national defence. Herlin was founding member of the Finnish branch of the [[European Cultural Foundation]]. He also founded the Kone Foundation, that supports cultural and sociological research; one notable support project was publishing of genealogy book [[Genealogia Sursilliana]]. Heikki H. Herlin had a broad language knowledge, which he developed continuously. While he could communicate in every language which were most important for his business, he also studied exotic languages; for him it was a matter of honour to be able to give at least a vote of thanks in the local language, wherever he visited representing either his company or Finnish trade and industry delegations. == Personal life == Heikki H. Herlin lived in the Thorsvik Estate, which his father had bought. He met there his future wife Anna Oittinen at the turn of the 1930s; she had come there as a nurse to take care of his mother Hanna Herlin. During 1931–1936 the couple got three daughters and one son, Pekka Herlin, who inherited his father's position as Kone leader. == Board memberships == * Peltiteos Oy (1933–) * Co-operative Finnish Fair (1938–) * Finnish Metal Industry Association (1938–1965) * Walter Ahlström Foundation (1938–1944) * [[Kulosaari]] Coeducational School (1940–1953) * [[Kone|Kone Oy]] (1941–1987) * Otanmäki committee (1942–1944) * [[Vanajan Autotehdas|Yhteissisu Oy]] (1943–1946) * Finnish Metal Industry Association (1944–) * Kulosaari Neighbourhood Fund Foundation (1944–) * Engineering office Levator Oy (1946–) * Mutual life insurance company [[Sampo Group|Sampo]] (1947–) * Co-operative Metex (1948–1965) * Christian Culture Foundation (1948–1952; 1953) * Helsinki War Invalid Foundation (1949–) * [[Rotary International]] (1950–1951) * National Defence Support (1951–1959) * Finnish Reserve Officer Federation Support Association (1951–) * Finnish Cultural Fund (1951–) * Finnish Foreign Trade Federation (1951–) * [[Moral Re-Armament]] Support Foundation (1952–) * Christian-Social Working Centre (1952–) * [[Elisa (company)|Helsinki Telephone Co-operative]] (1959–1973) * Fédération International de la Manutention (1966–1968) * Finnish Technicians' Society (1934–1945) * Oy Konela Ab == Awards == * [[Order of the Lion of Finland|Commander of the Order of the Lion of Finland, 1st Class]] * [[Order of the Cross of Liberty|Cross of Liberty, 3rd Class, with swords]] * [[Order of the White Rose of Finland|Knight of the White Rose of Finland, 1st Class]] * [[Order of the Cross of Liberty|Cross of Liberty, 4th Class, peace-time merits]] * Memorial Medal for [[Winter War]] * Memorial Medal for [[Continuation War]] * Civil Defence Medal of Merit, 2nd Class * [[Order of the Yugoslav Star|Yugoslav Great Star]] ([[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]) * [[Order of the Flag of the Republic of Hungary|Hungarian Flag Cross]] ([[Hungarian People's Republic|Hungary]]) * [[Order of Glory (Tunisia)|Grand-officer of the Order of Glory]] ([[Tunisia]]) * vuorineuvos (1953) * [[Honorary doctorate|Honorary Doctor]] of [[Economics]] ([[University of Rostock]], [[GDR]], 1969) * Honorary Doctor of Arts ([[University of Helsinki]]) == Sources == {{DEFAULTSORT:Herlin, Heikki H}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1989 deaths]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Helsinki]] [[Category:Finnish businesspeople]] [[Category:Finnish chief executives]] [[Category:Herlin family|Heikki]] [[Category:Kone- ja Siltarakennus]] [[Category:20th-century Finnish businesspeople]]

{{multiple issues| {{Unreferenced|date=November 2012}} {{POV|date=November 2012}} }} '''Indian Audit and Accounts Service (IA&AS)''' is an Indian Central Government service, free of control from any executive authority, under the [[Comptroller and Auditor General of India]]. The officers of the Indian Audit and Accounts Service serve in an audit managerial capacity, in the Indian Audit and Accounts Department. IA&AS is responsible for auditing the accounts of the Union and State governments and public sector organizations, and for maintaining the accounts of State governments. Its role is somewhat similar to the US [[GAO]] and [[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)]]. The service can be divided into officers looking after accounting and audit issues pertaining to the Union government and the State governments, and those manning the department's headquarters. The state accounts and audit offices are headed by Accountants General or Principal Accountants General. They are functionally equivalent; only the designations vary. Major states have three Principal Accountants General (PAsG) or Accountants General (AsG), each heading Accounts and Entitlement (i.e., compiling state accounts, maintaining pension accounts, loan accounts, etc.), General and Social Sector Audit (GSSA) or Economic and Revenue Sector Audit (ERSA). The equivalent officers at the Central level are Principal Directors (PDs) or Directors General (DsG). The PDs, DsG, AsG and PAsG report to Additional Deputy CAG (also called ADAI, for historical reasons) or Deputy CAG (called DAI, again for historical reasons). The Deputy CAGs are the highest-ranked officers in the service. After training, the Officer Trainees are posted as Assistant Accountant General Assistant Directors a Junior Grade Group A later promoted to Deputy Accountants General (DAsG) or Deputy Directors (DDs) a Senior time scale. Subsequent to their promotion, they become Senior Deputy Accountants General (Sr.DAsG) or Directors. All officers below the rank of AG/PD are also called Group Officers as they are generally in charge of a group in the office. ==Recruitment and training== Recruitment to the IA&AS is through the joint competitive examinations (the Union Public Service Commission) and through promotion from the subordinate cadre. Once recruited to the IA&AS, the directly recruited officers are trained mainly at the [http://www.naaa.gov.in National Academy of Audit and Accounts], [[Shimla]], Himachal Pradesh, India. The training is split into two phases. Phase-1 involves giving a theoretical background to the students on concepts of Government and commercial auditing and accounting. Phase-2 gives emphasis on practical training. The training involves modules where Officer Trainees are attached to the Reserve Bank of India,TISS-Mumbai,SEBI the National Institute of Public Finance and Policy, NIFM Faridabad, the Bureau of Parliamentary Studies and the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad. The Officer Trainees are also given an international exposure through attachment with London School of Economics and Political Science and [[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)]]. == Sanctioned strength == Sanctioned strength of IA&AS Cadre (As on 01.09.2016)
Deputy Comptroller and Auditor General: 6
Additional Deputy Comptroller and Auditor General: 7
Principal Accountant General: 56
Senior Administrative Grade: 128
Junior Administrative Grade: 147 (Selection Grade 74 and Ordinary Grade 73)
Senior Time Scale: 263
Junior Time Scale: 88
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Public Services of India}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Audit and Accounts Service}} [[Category:Accounting in India]] [[Category:Central Civil Services (India)]]
