revision.text:
{{about||the former governor of the U.S. state of Washington|Mike Lowry|the Gaelic footballer|Mick Lowry}} {{Use Irish English|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Michael Lowry | honorific-suffix = [[Teachta Dála|TD]] | image = | office = [[Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport|Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications]] | taoiseach = [[John Bruton]] | term_start = 15 December 1994 | term_end = 30 November 1996 | predecessor = [[Brian Cowen]] | successor = John Bruton | office2 = [[Teachta Dála]] | term_start2 = [[Irish general election, 2016|February 2016]] | term_end2 = | constituency2 = [[Tipperary (Dáil constituency)|Tipperary]] | term_start3 = [[Irish general election, 1987|February 1987]] | term_end3 = [[Irish general election, 2016|February 2016]] | constituency3 = [[Tipperary North (Dáil constituency)|Tipperary North]] | birth_name = Michael Gerard Lowry | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|03|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Thurles]], [[County Tipperary]], Ireland | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Irish people|Irish]] | party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] (since 1997) | otherparty = [[Fine Gael]] (until 1997) | spouse = Breda Ahern {{small|(m. 1981)}} | children = 2 | education = | alma_mater = [[University College Cork]] | website = {{URL|michaellowry.ie}} |}} '''Michael Gerard Lowry''' (born 13 March 1953) is an Irish [[Independent politician|Independent]] politician who has served as a [[Teachta Dála]] (TD) since 1987, currently for the [[Tipperary (Dáil constituency)|Tipperary]] constituency. He previously served as [[Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport|Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications]] from 1994 to 1996 and [[Fine Gael|Chairman of the Fine Gael Parliamentary Party]] from 1993 to 1994.<ref name=oireachtas_db>{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/members-hist/default.asp?housetype=0&HouseNum=30&MemberID=645&ConstID=171|title=Mr. Michael Lowry|work=Oireachtas Members Database|accessdate=27 September 2009}}</ref>
Lowry is a former Chairman of the [[Fine Gael]] party and was [[Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport|Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications]] between 1994 and 1996. He resigned from his ministry in some controversy. [[Fine Gael]] barred him from standing for the party again. Thereafter he ran as an [[Independent politician|Independent]] candidate and has maintained his seat in the Dáil ever since. The [[Moriarty Tribunal]] concluded "beyond doubt" that Lowry was a [[Tax evasion|tax evader]] and had assisted businessman [[Denis O'Brien]]'s [[Esat Digifone licence controversy|Esat Digiphone]] consortium in acquiring a lucrative mobile phone licence in the mid-1990s, during Lowry's time as Communications Minister. O'Brien went on to become one of the richest men in Ireland.<ref name="RTÉ-Moriarty-findings"/>
Lowry initiated a [[defamation]] lawsuit against an ''[[Irish Independent]]'' journalist, Sam Smyth, over an article that Smyth had written regarding the Moriarty Tribunal as well as comments that Smyth made on a [[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]] show. The lawsuit was thrown out of several courts and Lowry was ordered to pay Smyth's legal costs. More recently his relationship with Kevin Phelan has come under scrutiny, with the emergence of [[Lowry Tapes|a recorded conversation]] in which Lowry claims to have made an undeclared payment of €250,000.
Despite being the subject of a criminal investigation resulting from several scandals pursuing him from his time in office, he continues to be very popular in his constituency.<ref>{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Lynch|url=http://www.herald.ie/national-news/if-hed-been-more-careful-he-could-now-be-taoiseach-2590894.html|title=If he'd been more careful, he could now be Taoiseach|newspaper=[[Evening Herald]]|date=23 March 2011|accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref>
==Early life== Lowry was born in [[County Tipperary]] and educated at [[Thurles]] CBS. He was elected to [[North Tipperary County Council]] in 1979. In the early 1980s he was a [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] administrator, and was the youngest-ever Chairman of the [[Tipperary GAA]] Board.<ref name=IT-still-topping-polls>{{cite news|first=Colm|last=Keena|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2011/0323/1224292846826.html|title=Still topping polls despite frequent falls from grace|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|date=23 March 2011|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref> He runs a commercial refrigeration business, Streamline Enterprises, that he founded in controversial circumstances in 1988.<ref name=IT-still-topping-polls/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://streamlineenterprises.ie/|title=Streamline Enterprises: Streamline Enterprises are market leaders in Refrigeration, Air Conditioning and HVAC solutions: Welcome to Streamline Enterprises Website}}</ref> Later, as chairman of the [[Semple Stadium]] Development Committee, he was involved in raising the necessary funds for the refurbishment of the stadium in preparation for the All-Ireland Centenary Hurling final in 1984.<ref name=IT-still-topping-polls/>
==National politics== Lowry was first elected to [[Dáil Éireann]] as a [[Fine Gael]] TD for [[Tipperary North (Dáil constituency)|Tipperary North]] at the [[Irish general election, 1987|1987 general election]] and in 1993 he became Chairman of the Fine Gael Parliamentary Party.
In 1994 he was appointed [[Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport|Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications]] in the [[24th Government of Ireland|Rainbow Coalition]] government.
A succession of political scandals pursued Lowry throughout his time in office. These included [[Esat Digifone licence controversy|allegations of irregularities]] relating to the granting of a mobile phone licence to [[BT Ireland|Esat Telecom]], which were later investigated by the [[Moriarty Tribunal]], plans for the [[Luas|Dublin Light Rail System]] and the closure of rural post offices. The 1997 [[McCracken Tribunal]] revealed supermarket tycoon [[Ben Dunne (entrepreneur)|Ben Dunne]] had paid IR£395,000 for an extension to Lowry's home in Tipperary.<ref>{{cite news|first=Sam|last=Smyth|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/sam-smyth-the-twobit-politician-who-committed-daylight-robbery-2590520.html|title=The two-bit politician who committed daylight robbery|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]] |date=23 March 2011|accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> The Tribunal concluded that Lowry had evaded tax.
This allegation prompted Lowry's resignation from the Cabinet in November 1996. Taoiseach [[John Bruton]] announced that Lowry would not be allowed to stand as a Fine Gael candidate at the next election, and he resigned from the party.
Lowry announced that he would stand as an independent candidate in the [[Irish general election, 1997|1997 general election]]. He topped the poll in his constituency in that election, and did so again in the [[Irish general election, 2002|2002]] and [[Irish general election, 2007|2007]] general elections.<ref name=elecs_irl>{{cite web|url=http://electionsireland.org/candidate.cfm?ID=3737|title=Michael Lowry|work=ElectionsIreland.org|accessdate=27 September 2009}}</ref>
Lowry is backed by a strong local organisation in Tipperary, known informally as "Team Lowry".<ref>{{cite news|first=Eimear|last=Ni Bhraonain|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/its-the-personal-touch-that-earns-such-a-loyal-following-2595420.html|title=It's the personal touch that earns such a loyal following|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref>
Lowry was re-elected to represent Tipperary North at the [[Irish general election, 2011|2011 general election]], heading the poll on the [[PRSTV|1st count]] with 14,010 votes.<ref name="2001_elecs">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/election2011/results/tipperary-north.html |title=Tipperary North |accessdate=26 February 2011 |publisher=RTÉ News |date=28 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228221747/http://www.rte.ie/news/election2011/results/tipperary-north.html |archivedate=28 February 2011 |df= }}</ref> He was elected again, for [[Tipperary (Dáil constituency)|Tipperary]], at the [[Irish general election, 2016|2016 general election]]. He voted for [[Enda Kenny]] as Taoiseach on 6 May 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstalk.com/election2016/Enda-Kenny-Taoiseach-Cabinet-Dail-votes-Independents|title=Enda Kenny is re-elected as Taoiseach in the Dáil|work=Newstalk|date=6 May 2016}}</ref> Shortly after [[Ceann Comhairle]] [[Seán Ó Fearghaíl]] confirmed the result, Lowry was seen to offer a handshake to Kenny.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.carlow-nationalist.ie/2016/05/06/video-enda-kenny-elected-taoiseach-after-day-of-drama/|title=KENNY ELECTED TAOISEACH, SHANE ROSS REVEALS APPOINTMENT TO TRANSPORT MINISTRY|work=Carlow Nationalist|date=6 May 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513202632/http://www.carlow-nationalist.ie/2016/05/06/video-enda-kenny-elected-taoiseach-after-day-of-drama/|archivedate=13 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Business interests== Lowry has directorships listed with the Companies Registration Office. He has two roles with Garuda Ltd, a manufacturer of electric domestic appliances; Abbeygreen Consulting, which involves construction work and special trades; and Gdlc Business Consultants Ltd., a business and management consultancy registered in Dublin. He also has an unlimited company called Glebeland Farm, which manages his bloodstock and livestock interests.<ref name=examiner-sale-of-wedding-morn-foal>{{cite news|first=Conor|last=Ryan|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/lowrys-stock-rises-with-sale-of-wedding-morn-foal-215661.html|title=Lowry's stock rises with sale of Wedding Morn foal|newspaper=Irish Examiner|date=1 December 2012|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref>
Lowry had some success with horse racing as a quarter-partner in the MALM partnership, but has in recent times taken to flat-race breeding.<ref name=examiner-sale-of-wedding-morn-foal/>
Lowry owned a horse called "Wedding Morn", though the price he paid for the horse is not known. The horse was covered by Coolmore's "[[Danehill Dancer]]", from the stable of [[John Magnier]]. He would have paid up to €75,000 to have the horse covered. Another horse, "Probably", was sold by Lowry, which was the progeny of Wedding Morn. Wedding Morn was delivered of three foals including Probably, and the three were sold for a total of €410,000 by Lowry between 2009 and 2011.<ref>{{cite news|first=Conor|last=Ryan|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/archives/2012/0711/world/lowry-has-1m-reasons-to-be-happy-200396.html|title=Lowry has €1m reasons to be happy|newspaper=Irish Examiner|date=11 July 2012|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> Lowry sold Wedding Morn in 2012 for €361,849.<ref>{{cite news|first=Conor|last=Ryan|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/lowrys-bloodstock-secures-813k-215991.html|title=Lowry's bloodstock secures €813k|newspaper=Irish Examiner|date=5 December 2012|accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref>
==Moriarty Tribunal: investigation and results== One of the remits of the [[Moriarty Tribunal]], which sat from 1997 to 2011, was the investigation of payments to Lowry. In early 2007 Lowry announced that he had made a full and final settlement of all outstanding payments with the [[Revenue Commissioners]] in response to the findings concerning his tax evasion. His company Garuda had to pay €1.2 million after a Revenue audit. He also paid almost €200,000 to settle his personal taxes.<ref>{{cite news|first=Fintan|last=O'Toole|authorlink=Fintan O'Toole|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2009/0421/1224245071062.html|title=A country still in thrall to the likes of Lowry|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=21 April 2009|accessdate=27 September 2009}}</ref>
In March 2011 the second and final report from the Moriarty Tribunal found that, during his time as Communications Minister, Michael Lowry assisted businessman [[Denis O'Brien]]'s consortium Esat Digiphone in acquiring a lucrative mobile phone licence in the mid-1990s which ultimately made O'Brien one of the richest men in Ireland.<ref name="RTÉ-Moriarty-findings">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0322/moriarty_background.html|title=Lowry helped O'Brien get mobile licence|work=[[RTÉ News]]|date=22 March 2011|accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref>
It concluded "beyond doubt" that Lowry gave what it termed "substantive information to Denis O'Brien, of significant value and assistance to him in securing the licence".<ref name="RTÉ-Moriarty-findings"/> The Tribunal report found that Lowry, displayed "an appreciable interest" in the process and had "irregular interactions with interested parties at its most sensitive stages".<ref name="RTÉ-Moriarty-findings"/> It also found that one of Lowry's interventions, which cut the selection process to the advantage of Esat, was "disgraceful" and "insidious", and that he had misled the Government, his party leader [[John Bruton]] and his own civil servants to influence the selection process in Esat's favour.<ref name=Indo-lowry-disgrace>{{cite news|first=Shane|last=Phelan|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/lowrys-disgrace-2590572.html|title=Lowry's disgrace|work=Irish Independent|date=23 March 2011|accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref>
The tribunal also found that Lowry sought to procure unwarranted rent increases that over a seven-year period would have benefited businessman Ben Dunne. Lowry sought to influence the outcome of an arbitration being conducted in 1995 in relation to the rent payable by the then state-owned [[Telecom Éireann]] for Marlborough House to a company owned and controlled by Dunne. The report said that the matter was "profoundly corrupt to a degree that was nothing short of breathtaking".<ref name="RTÉ-Moriarty-findings"/>
The report also summarised the cumulative payments made to Lowry, and says "In aggregating the known payments from Denis O'Brien to Michael Lowry, it is apposite to note that, between the granting of the second GSM licence to Esat Digiphone in May 1996, and the transmission of £420,000 sterling to complete the purchase of the latter of Lowry's English properties in December 1999, O'Brien had made or facilitated payments to Lowry of £147,000 sterling, £300,000 sterling and a benefit equivalent to a payment in the form of O'Brien's support for a loan of £420,000 sterling."<ref name="RTÉ-Moriarty-findings"/>
Lowry had addressed the Dáil saying that if he had been trying to hide a lot of money he would have "put it in an offshore account", implying that no such account existed. The Tribunal found that he actually had at least four such accounts that he used for the purpose of evading tax, and had not disclosed these accounts to the previous McCracken Tribunal.<ref name=IT-still-topping-polls/>
Lowry rejected the Moriarty report, claiming that it was flawed and that the assumptions and conclusions that Justice Moriarty arrived at were totally baseless.<ref name=Indo-lowry-disgrace/> Nonetheless the [[Criminal Assets Bureau]] and the Bureau of Fraud were called in on 29 March 2011 to begin investigating his finances, since his €1.4 million settlement with the revenue commissioners did not grant him immunity from prosecution.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0329/lowrym.html|title=CAB investigating Michael Lowry finances|work=RTÉ News|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref>
On 31 March 2011, following the [[Moriarty Tribunal|Moriarty Report]]'s publication, the Dáil passed an all-party motion calling on Lowry to voluntarily resign his seat.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0331/moriarty.html#videol|title=Lowry Motion passed without vote|work=RTÉ News|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref>
==''Lowry v. Sam Smyth''== In 2010 Lowry launched a [[defamation]] lawsuit against ''[[Irish Independent]]'' journalist Sam Smyth, over an article Smyth had written regarding the Moriarty Tribunal<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/tribunal-will-reveal-findings-on-money-trail-to-exminister-2196088.html|title=Tribunal will reveal findings on money trail to ex-minister|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=27 May 2010|accessdate=27 May 2010}}</ref> as well as comments Smyth had made on a [[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]] show describing Lowry as having been "caught with his hand in the till."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/0210/breaking19.html|title=Lowry loses High Court action|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=10 February 2012|accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> Smyth defended the defamation claim, stating he "did not call Michael Lowry TD a thief, but did believe he was a liar and a tax cheat".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1218/1224285836003.html|title=Journalist says he called TD a tax cheat not a thief|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=12 December 2010|accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> Lowry's defamation lawsuit was thrown out in the Circuit court,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/1006/lowrym_smyths.html|title=Sam Smyth awarded legal costs against Lowry|work=RTÉ News|date=6 October 2011|accessdate=6 October 2011}}</ref> and again on appeal to the High Court.<ref name=rte-high-court-dismisses-lowry>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2012/0210/lowrym.html|title=High Court dismisses Lowry defamation appeal|work=RTÉ News|date=10 February 2012|accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> High Court Justice Nicholas Kearns noted that Lowry "did not dispute that he engaged in tax fraud",<ref name=rte-high-court-dismisses-lowry/> and ordered Lowry to pay Smyth's legal costs.<ref>{{cite news|first=Dearbhail|last=McDonald|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/a-good-day-for-journalism-as-lowry-loses-libel-appeal-3016622.html|title='A good day for journalism' as Lowry loses libel appeal|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=11 February 2012|accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref>
==Undeclared land interest== It emerged in October 2012 that Lowry owned land in Wigan which he had failed to declare in his register of members' interests. Between 2001 and 2003 the 25-acre site had been owned by Liam Carroll and Vineacre Ltd, a UK property company owned by him and Lowry. Vineacre Ltd was removed from the title in 2003 and Lowry declared his Vineacre interest until the company was dissolved in 2008. The land then became Lowry's and Carroll's in their own names, but he failed to declare his interest from 2008 onwards.<ref>{{cite news|first=Conor|last=Ryan|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/links-between-lowrys-worthless-wigan-land-and-deals-probed-by-moriarty-215576.html|title=Links between Lowry's 'worthless' Wigan land and deals probed by Moriarty|newspaper=Irish Examiner|date=30 November 2012|accessdate=30 November 2012}}</ref>
On 6 November 2012 Lowry amended his declaration to the [[Oireachtas]] to include the land interest, despite claiming previously that the land was "worthless". An unprecedented 380 complaints were made by members of the public in relation to the scandal, partly prompted by an article written by author Elaine Byrne.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/lowry-may-face-standards-probe-after-380-complaints-3312122.html|title=Lowry may face standards probe after 380 complaints|newspaper=Sunday Independent|date=2 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Elaine|last=Byrne|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/stop-giving-out-about-lowry-and-make-an-official-complaint-instead-3281694.html|title=Stop giving out about Lowry and make an official complaint instead|newspaper=Sunday Independent|date=4 November 2012|accessdate=4 November 2012}}</ref> According to rules, the property must be worth more than €13,000 to be declared an interest. Lowry claimed the complaints were part of an "orchestrated campaign" against him.<ref>{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Brennan|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/public-inquiry-to-examine-lowrys-land-share-in-uk-3309789.html|title=Public inquiry to examine Lowry's land share in UK|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=29 November 2012|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref>
As of December 2012 the probe into Lowry's failure to declare the land interest had been transferred to the Standards in Public Office Commission (SIPO).<ref>{{cite news|first=Conor|last=Ryan|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/archives/2012/1129/world/lowryaposs-uk-land-interest-to-be-probed-215450.html|title=Lowry's UK land interest to be probed|newspaper=Irish Examiner|date=29 November 2012|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref>
==Relationship with Kevin Phelan== {{further information|Lowry Tapes}} In March 2013 Northern Ireland land scout Kevin Phelan revealed that Lowry had made payments to him in 2002, of which only half had been disclosed to the [[Moriarty Tribunal]]. The ''Sunday Independent'' released a secret recording of a telephone conversation made by Phelan, in which Lowry asks for nothing to be revealed about the payment to the tribunal.<ref>{{cite news|first=Colm|last=Keena|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/payment-from-michael-lowry-was-part-of-agreement-says-land-scout-1.1330321|title='Payment from Michael Lowry was part of agreement, says land scout'|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=19 March 2013|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> This was also broadcast on ''[[Tonight with Vincent Browne]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=98152 |title=Lowry tape broadcast |work=TV3 News |date=15 March 2013 |accessdate=15 March 2013 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/michael-lowry-kevin-phelan-conversation-833051-Mar2013/|title=Gardaí examining Lowry tape as conversation is aired on national TV: Independent TD Michael Lowry can be heard making reference to a £250,000 payment which he said he never declared|work=TheJournal.ie|date=15 March 2013|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> In November 2015, it was announced that Lowry has launched [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]] proceedings against [[Independent News & Media|INM]] in relation to the tapes.
==Tax affairs== Lowry availed himself of the Tax Amnesty in 1993.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/td-availed-of-1993-last-chance-tax-amnesty-29450040.html|title=TD availed of 1993 'last chance' tax amnesty|date=6 July 2006|accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref> He made a settlement with the Revenue again in 2003. In 2007 he paid a settlement of €192,000 which was due to the emergence of secret payments to him by businessman [[Ben Dunne (entrepreneur)|Ben Dunne]]. His company Garuda Limited made a settlement of €1.1m in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/michael-lowrys-firm-in-11m-tax-settlement-26417152.html|title=Michael Lowry's firm in 1.1m tax settlement|date=8 October 2006|accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref> In 2014 he faced five charges, including knowingly completing incorrect tax returns on a number of dates between 2003 and 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2007/0925/93931-tax/|title=Michael Lowry to face trial in Dublin Circuit Court|date=5 December 2015|accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref> In 2018 he was found guilty on one of the charges, relating to a €372,000 payment received in 2002 but not recorded until 2006.<ref>{{cite news |last1=O'Donnell |first1=Orla |title=Lowry guilty of filing incorrect corporation tax return |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/courts/2018/0626/973306-michael-lowry-court/ |accessdate=26 June 2018 |work=RTE.ie |date=26 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==State board appointments lobbying== In January 2015 it was revealed that he lobbied Taoiseach Enda Kenny to have his female former press adviser reappointed to a State board. Lowry passed a note to the Taoiseach in the Dáil chamber asking him to consider re-appointing Valerie O'Reilly, who runs her own successful public relations agency, to the board of the National Transport Authority (NTA). The note read "Taoiseach, would you please consider re-appointing Valerie O'Reilly to the board of the NTA. A woman, bright, intelligent and not bad looking either!" Her initial appointment by the previous government in March 2010 provoked charges of cronyism. The incident came just three months after Kenny and Fine Gael were engulfed in another cronyism scandal involving John McNulty and the [[Irish Museum of Modern Art]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Daniel|last=McConnell|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/exclusive-exminister-passes-note-to-taoiseach-seeking-crony-appointment-30934975.html|title=Ex-minister passes note to Taoiseach seeking 'crony' appointment|work=Sunday Independent|accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref> The then [[Fianna Fáil]] senator [[Averil Power]] expressed surprise at the tone of the note and said: "She probably does have strong business credentials, but to be referred to in this ''[[Father Ted]]'' 'lovely girls' sort of way is every women's worst nightmare. It also shows that we need far greater transparency when it comes to State board appointments".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Connolly|first1=Shaun|title=Lovely girls' note embroils Taoiseach in controversy|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/lovely-girls-note-embroils-taoiseach-in-controversy-308932.html|work=Irish Examiner|accessdate=27 January 2015|date=26 January 2015}}</ref>
Lowry was also revealed to have lobbied Minister for Transport [[Paschal Donohoe]] on the same matter. Donohoe told journalists at UCD that he had been "briefly" approached by Lowry. Lowry himself confirmed he had spoken to Donohoe in the Seanad chamber's anteroom. "I had been following a debate on a health-related issue in the Seanad and, out of courtesy, I informed Mr Donohoe, when I met him, that I had sent a note to the Taoiseach on the reappointment" claimed Lowry. When asked to respond to media coverage of the affair, Lowry said: "It is a load of nonsense and, frankly, more irritating than anything else."<ref>{{cite web|last1=O'Regan|first1=Michael|title=Independent TD responds to reappointment controversy|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/reaction-to-note-political-correctness-gone-mad-lowry-1.2080477|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=27 January 2015|date=27 January 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox royalty | image =Prince Moulay Ali ben Driss Alaoui.jpg | image_size =200px | name = Prince Moulay Ali | title = [[Morocco|Prince of Morocco]] | full name = | crown = | suc-type = | royal house = [[Alaouite dynasty]] | father = Prince ''Moulay'' Idriss | mother = ''Lalla'' Joumala | birth_date = 1924 | birth_place = [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]] | death_date = 1988 | death_place = | place of burial = | religion = [[Islam]] | spouse = [[Lalla Fatima Zohra|Princess Lalla Fatima Zohra]]
(1961-1988) | issue = [[Princess Lalla Joumala Alaoui|Princess ''Lalla'' Joumala Alaoui]]
[[Moulay Abdallah ben Ali Alaoui|''Sharif Moulay'' Abdallah Alaoui]]
[[Moulay Youssef Alaoui|''Sharif Moulay'' Youssef Alaoui]] }} ''Prince'' '''Moulay Ali''' (1924–1988) was a member of the reigning [[Alaouite dynasty]] of Morocco. He held many senior positions including ambassador to France (1964–1966), CEO of [[ONA Group]] (1980–1985), President of [[Cosumar]] and CEO of banks such as ''Banque Marocaine pour l’Expansion Economique'' and ''Soc de Banque et de Crédit''.{{cite web|author1=Christopher Buyers|title=The Alawi Dynasty GENEALOGY|url=http://www.royalark.net/Morocco/morocco11.htm|accessdate=5 June 2014|quote=H.H. Prince Mulay ‘Ali. b. at Marrakesh, 1924, educ. Lycée Lyautey, Casablanca. Special Adviser to King Hassan II, Ambassador to France 1964-1966, Special Envoy to Iran 1966, Presdt COSUMAR National Sugar Co 1966, Banque Marocaine pour l’Expansion Economique, Soc de Banque et de Crédit, Omnium Nord Africain 1980-1985, etc. Rcvd: GO of the Orders of the Throne of Morocco, Legion of Honour of France (x.6.1963), Equatorial Star of Gabon, etc. m. at the Dar al-Makhzin, Rabat, 16th August 1961, H.R.H. Princess Lalla Fatima az-Zahra (b. at the Dar al-Makhzin, Rabat, 29th June 1929 ), eldest daughter of his paternal uncle, H.M. Sidi Muhammad V, King of Morocco, and Amir al-Mu’minin, by his second wife. He d. 1988, having had issue, two sons and one daughter:}} ==Family== He was the son of Prince [[Prince Moulay Idriss|Moulay Idriss]] (son of [[Yusef of Morocco|Sultan Moulay Youssef]]) and Lalla Joumala, a daughter of ''Moulay'' Mustafa by his wife which was a daughter of [[Hassan I of Morocco|Sultan Hassan I]]. Thus was a cousin of [[Hassan II of Morocco|Hassan II]] both on his father's and mother's side. He studied in Lycée Lyautey in Casablanca. On 16 August 1961 he married his cousin [[Lalla Fatima Zohra|Princess Lalla Fatima Zohra]], an older sister of Hassan II, with whom he had a daughter and two sons: *[[Princess Lalla Joumala Alaoui]] (b. 1962). *[[Moulay Abdallah ben Ali Alaoui|Sharif Moulay Abdallah Alaoui]] (born c. 1965). *[[Moulay Youssef Alaoui|Sharif Moulay Youssef Alaoui]] (born c. 1969). ==Honours== * Grand Officer of the [[Order of the Throne]] (Kingdom of Morocco).[http://www.royalark.net/Morocco/morocco11.htm Royal Ark] * Grand Officer of the [[Legion of Honor|Order of the Legion of Honor]] (French Republic, 06/1963). * Grand Officer of the [[Order of the Equatorial Star of Gabon]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alaoui, Ali}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:Moroccan princes]] [[Category:Alaouite dynasty]] [[Category:People from Marrakesh]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Morocco to France]] [[Category:Alumni of Lycée Lyautey (Casablanca)]] [[Category:Moroccan chief executives]] [[Category:Moroccan businesspeople]] [[Category:Moroccan exiles in Madagascar]] [[Category:Moroccan bankers]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the Throne]] [[Category:Grand Officiers of the Légion d'honneur]]

[[Spinster Stakes]] (1972)
[[Spinaway Stakes]] (1972)
[[Test Stakes]] (1972) | awards = [[American Champion Two-Year-Old Filly]] (1971) | honours = | updated= }} '''Numbered Account''' (1969–1996) was an [[United States|American]] [[Thoroughbred]] racehorse who was voted the [[American Champion Two-Year-Old Filly]] of 1971.[http://www.tra-online.com/2yo_filly.html Thoroughbred Racing Associations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122123743/http://www.tra-online.com/2yo_filly.html |date=2012-01-22 }} She was bred and raced by [[Ogden Phipps]] and trained by [[Roger Laurin]].[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fe9LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Mu0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6937,1157441&dq=numbered-account+ogden+phipps&hl=en Spokane, Washington Spokesman-Review - November 5, 1971] On May 19, 1971, Numbered Account set a [[Fashion Stakes]] record of 0:57 2/5 for five furlongs on dirt at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]].[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/954223132.html?dids=954223132:954223132&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=May+20%2C+1971&author=&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=Numbered+Account+Excels+at+Big+A&pqatl=google Hartford Courant - May 20, 1971] On October 22, 1972, in winning the [[Spinster Stakes]] she equaled the [[Keeneland]] track record of 1:47 2/5 for 1 1/8 miles (9 furlongs) on dirt set by [[Round Table (horse)|Round Table]] in 1957.[https://www.nytimes.com/1972/10/28/archives/numbered-account-upsets-chou-croute.html New York Times - October 24, 1971] Numbered Account retired in 1974 after three years in racing having won fourteen of her twenty-two starts and $607,048. She was sent to [[broodmare]] duty at [[Claiborne Farm]] near [[Paris, Kentucky]]. Of her best foals, she was the dam of [[Graded stakes race|Grade 1]] winners [[Dance Number]] (by [[Northern Dancer]]) and [[Private Account]] (by [[Damascus (horse)|Damascus]]) who sired [[Personal Ensign]].[http://www.pedigreequery.com/progeny/numbered+account Numbered Account's progeny] She also appears twice in the pedigree of [[2014 Kentucky Derby]] winner [[California Chrome]].{{cite web|url=http://www.equineline.com/Free-5X-Pedigree.cfm?page_state=ORDER_AND_CONFIRM&reference_number=9074807®istry=T&horse_name=California%20Chrome&dam_name=Love%20the%20Chase&foaling_year=2011&nicking_stats_indicator=Y |title=California Chrome |publisher=Equineline |date=2014-03-07 |accessdate=2014-04-08}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.pedigreequery.com/numbered+account Numbered Account's pedigree and partial racing stats] [[Category:1969 racehorse births]] [[Category:1996 racehorse deaths]] [[Category:Racehorses bred in Kentucky]] [[Category:Racehorses trained in the United States]] [[Category:Eclipse Award winners]] [[Category:Phipps family]] [[Category:Thoroughbred family 1-x]]

revision.comment: update infobox
revision.text:
{{Infobox software |title = OpenCity |screenshot = File:Opencity small.png |developer = Duong-Khang Nguyen |platform = [[Cross-platform]] |released = 22 October 2009 |latest_release_date=2011 |latest_release_version=0.0.62 |license=[[GPLv2]]<ref>[https://sourceforge.net/p/opencity/code/HEAD/tree/trunk/opencity/COPYING copying] on sourceforge.net/p/opencity</ref> |genre = [[Single-player]] [[City-building game|City-building]] |website=http://www.opencity.info/ }} [[Image:OpenCity-0.0.5-mainstatusbar.jpg|thumb|Screenshot of OpenCity 0.0.5]] '''''OpenCity''''' is a [[free and open-source software]] 3D [[city-building game]] started in 2003 by France-based Vietnamese programmer Duong-Khang Nguyen. The game mechanics are similar to [[Simcity]],<ref name="chip"/> while the game developers don't strive to make it a direct Simcity [[Video game clone|clone]].
== Gameplay == In the game, the player builds a city by marking land as commercial, industrial or residential zones. Those zones depend on each other to grow. The player is also required to supply the city with power and connect the different zones by building roads.
==Origins and development== '''''OpenCity''''' is the product of programmer Duong-Khang Nguyen and 3D artist Frédéric Rodrigo. Nguyen was inspired by the open source game ''FreeReign''; when he realized that the ''FreeReign'' project was [[Abandonware|abandoned]] and the [[source code]] was not in the condition to be improved, he began development on his own city-building simulator.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100625040648/http://linux.softpedia.com/get/GAMES-ENTERTAINMENT/Simulation/Open-City-10890.shtml Open City 0.0.6.1] on [[Softpedia]] (archived, June 2009)</ref> The work in project started in 2003 with the registration on [[Sourceforge]].<ref name="sourceforge">[https://sourceforge.net/projects/opencity/ opencity] on sourceforge.net</ref> OpenCity is [[Free and open-source software]] due to the [[Software license|licensing]] as [[GPLv2]].<ref name="sourceforge"/> Contributions to the game came from the game's community in form of translation and quality testing.<ref>[http://www.opencity.info/en/Credits.html Credits] on the OpenCity website</ref> OpenCity is built on cross platform libraries and APIs like [[Simple DirectMedia Library]] and [[OpenGL]], which allows [[Source port|porting]] to various OSes and platforms, like [[Windows]], [[OS X]]<ref name=macobserver>[http://www.macshareware.com/review/opencity OpenCity 0.0.6] on Macshareware.com (August 24, 2013)</ref> and many [[Linux distribution]]s.<ref name="ubunutu"/><ref name="Fedora"/><ref name="debian"/>
Latest stable release branch is 0.0.62 with updates from 2011,<ref>[https://sourceforge.net/p/opencity/code/HEAD/tree/branches/0.0.6/ HEAD/tree/branches/0.0.6/] on [[sourceforge.net]]</ref> while the unstable development branch 0.0.7 has updates until 2015.<ref>[https://sourceforge.net/p/opencity/code/HEAD/tree/trunk/opencity/ HEAD/tree/trunk/opencity/] on [[sourceforge.net]]</ref>
== Reception == OpenCity achieved a broad spread as [[free and open-source]] and [[freeware]] video game,<ref name=macobserver/><ref>[http://www.computerbild.de/download/OpenCity-2255175.html OpenCity] on [[computerbild.de]] (May 2017)</ref> and was downloaded directly from [[Sourceforge]] between 2003 and May 2017 over 190,000 times according to the SF download statistic.<ref>[https://sourceforge.net/projects/opencity/files/stats/timeline?dates=2003-04-23+to+2017-07-16 opencity - stats] on [[sourceforge.net]] (May 2017)</ref> OpenCity was also directly integrated in many [[Linux distribution]]s: [[Fedora (linux distribution)|Fedora]],<ref name="Fedora">[http://rpms.remirepo.net/rpmphp/zoom.php?rpm=opencity Package: opencity] on rpms.remirepo.net</ref> [[Debian]],<ref name="debian">[https://packages.debian.org/search?searchon=sourcenames&keywords=opencity opencity] on packages.debian.org</ref> [[Arch Linux]], [[SUSE Linux|SuSE]], [[Slackware]], [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]],<ref name="ubunutu">[https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/precise/opencity/ OpenCity] on apps.ubuntu.com</ref> [[Pardus (operating system)|Pardus]], [[Frugalware]]. ''OpenCity'' has been reviewed as "well made 3D [[Video game remake|remake]]" of SimCity by [[Chip.de]] in 2013.<ref name="chip">[http://www.chip.de/downloads/OpenCity_23170816.html OpenCity 0.0.6.2] on [[Chip.de]] ''"OpenCity ist ein liebevoll gemachtes 3D-Remake des Spiele-Klassikers SimCity aus dem Jahre 1989."'' (in German, March 5, 2013)</ref>
== Gallery == <gallery mode=packed style="text-align:left"> Opencity-0.0.3-textured-terrain.png|Screenshot of version 0.0.3 OpenCity0.0.5.png|Screenshot of version 0.0.5 </gallery>
==See also== {{div col}} {{Portal|Video games|Free software}} * [[List of open source games]] * [[Lincity]] * [[SimCity]] * [[Simutrans]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{commons category|OpenCity}} * [http://www.opencity.info OpenCity homepage] * {{en icon}} [http://www.opencity.info/en/TutorialToolcircle.html OpenCity tutorial]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Opencity}} [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Open-source video games]] [[Category:City-building games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:Free software programmed in C++]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]]

revision.comment: Fix caps in section header and other minor fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''person-centered systems theory''' (German: Personzentrierte Systemtheorie) is a multi-level concept for the understanding of processes in [[psychotherapy]], [[counseling psychology|counseling]], [[coaching]] and [[clinical psychology]] under consideration of the interrelation of different levels – namely body, psyche, interpersonal and social processes. The concept has been developed by the German [[psychologist]] and [[psychotherapist]] [[Jürgen Kriz]].
Person-centered systems theory focuses on the necessity to reduce the incomprehensible complexity of (physical-chemical) [[stimulus (psychology)|stimuli]] by means of developing meaningful structures, patterns and rules in order to create a comprehensibly simple [[lifeworld]]. In this context, the question of stability as well as adaptive transition of the patterns is essential. Moreover, the historic perspective plays an important role because it provides the only access to an understanding of cultural patterns of explanation, metaphors, narrations as well as principles of reasoning. Here, Kriz introduces the term 'meaning [[attractor]]' (German: Sinnattraktor), which he describes as reduction of the vast possibilities of understanding and communication providing certainty and stability while limiting change, adaptation and creativity. Accordingly, it is an essential objective of person-centered systems theory to explain the effects of psychotherapy – and clinical processes in general – across various methods and schools of thought.
The [[Systems theory|systems theoretical]] (meta-) perspective of the person-centered systems theory refers to the systems-theoretical concepts of [[Gestalt psychology]] as well as humanistic psychotherapy ([[Carl Rogers]]' person-centered approach in particular) on the one hand and the relations to modern interdisciplinary [[systems theory]] (especially concepts of [[self-organization]] and [[Synergetics (Haken)|synergetics]]) on the other.
Contrary to the common systems approach in psychotherapy – as in [[systemic therapy (psychotherapy)|systemic]] and [[family therapy]] -, person-centered systems theory does not primarily focus on patterns of interactions and communication respectively but it takes into account the individual (the person in the sense of person-centered psychotherapy) as well as the underlying somatic processes and the cultural embedding of meaning processes. After all, central aspects like [[sense]], mind, [[Meaning (psychology)|meaning]] or [[Coherence theory of truth|coherence]] are related to the level of personal processes – even if these are substantially affected in their biographical and historical dynamic by social processes. A [[social system]] can define and/or prescribe something as meaningful – however, experiencing it as something meaningful is an intrinsic process of that person (first person perspective).
According to the model of synergetics, the patterns at each process level can be stable (for a given time) or show phase transitions. The former comes along with the positive aspects of predictability, familiarity and security, but the negative aspects of rigidity, solidification and non-adaptation. The latter is experienced as leaving old and inadequate patterns behind in order to reach new and better adapted ones. This has the positive aspects of novelty, creativity and uniqueness, but the negative aspects of instability, uncertainty and chaos. In the life-course of individuals, couples, families, groups and organizations, both phases of stability and of pattern transitions are necessary. Many symptoms and problems are related to over-stabilization of patterns, which have been good solutions to some requirements but are no longer adequate or functional due to the fact that the requirements have changed.
The person-centered systems theory describes the systemic effects of communication between humans (couples, families, organizations) as well as their interrelations through internal processes (perception, thinking, feeling) in its complex, non-linear interaction both [[Top-down and bottom-up design|bottom-up and top-down]].
Kriz (2017) provides a comprehensive presentation and discussion of the person-centered systems theory.
==Selected bibliography==
* Kriz, Jürgen (2017). Subjekt und Lebenswelt. Personzentrierte Systemtheorie für Psychotherapie, Beratung und Coaching (Subject and lifeworld. Person-centered systems theory for psychotherapy, counseling and coaching). Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht. {{ISBN|978-3-525-49163-8}}. *Kriz, Jürgen (2013). Person-Centred Approach and Systems Theory. In: Cornelius-White, M., Motschnig, R. & Lux, M. (eds.): Interdisciplinary Handbook of the Person-Centered Approach: Research and Theory. New York: Springer 261-276 *Kriz, Jürgen (2009). Cognitive and Interactive Patterning: Processes of creating meaning. In: Jaan Valsiner, Peter C. M. Molenaar, Maria C. D. P. Lyra & Nandita Chaudhary (eds.): Dynamic Process Methodology in the Social and Developmental Sciences. New York: Springer, 619-650 *Kriz, Jürgen (2008). Self-Actualization: Person-Centred Approach and Systems Theory. PCCS-books. Ross-on-Wye, UK *Cornelius-White, Jeffrey H.D. & Kriz, Jürgen (2008). The Formative Tendency: Person-centred Systems Theory, Interdependence and Human Potential. In: Brian Levitt (ed.): Reflections on human potential: The person-centred approach as a positive psychology. Ross-on-Wye (UK): PCCS-books, 116-130 *Kriz, Jürgen (2001).Self-Organization of Cognitive and Interactional Processes. In: Matthies, M., Malchow, H. & Kriz, J. (eds.): Integrative Systems Approaches to Natural and Social Dynamics. Heidelberg: Springer, 517-537 *Kriz, Jürgen (1991). Mental Health: Its Conception in Systems Theory. An Outline of the Person-Centered System Approach. In: Pelaez, M.J. (ed.): Comparative Sociology of Family, Health & Education XX, (Malaga, Espania), 6061-6083
== External links ==
*[http://www.gracepointwellness.org/91-psychotherapy/article/29024-an-interview-with-jurgen-kriz-on-the-topic-of-self-actualization-and-rogerian-person-centered-psychotherapy Interview with Jürgen Kriz on the topic of Self- Actualization and Rogerian Person Centered Psychotherapy]. *[http://www.jkriz.de/jk-pcst.htm Towards a Synthesis: Person-Centered Systems Theory. English translation of the last chapter of Jürgen Kriz: Grundkonzepte der Psychotherapie (Essential concepts of psychotherapy). Weinheim: Beltz/PVU 1985, rev. edition 1989]. *[http://www.jkriz.de/engl-tx.htm List of English publications by Jürgen Kriz - mostly dealing with person-centered systems theory].
[[Category:Psychotherapy]] [[Category:Counseling]] [[Category:Coaching]] [[Category:Systems theory]]

{{Infobox person | name = Peter E. Haas Jr. | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1947}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = United States | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = President and CEO of the [[Levi Strauss & Co]] | education = B.A. [[Stanford University]] | net_worth = $775 Million [[USD]] (1999)[http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/092499/bus_forbes1.html#.WOTGX2_DG00 Jacksonville Times-Union: "Forbes 400 Richest-List - The Wealthiest of America's Wealthy"] 1999 | occupation = businessman | spouse = Joanne Christensen (until her death)
Ginnie Haas | children = ''with Christensen:''
--Jennifer Haas
--Daniel Haas
--Bradley Haas | parents = Josephine Baum Haas
[[Peter E. Haas]] | family = [[Rhoda Haas Goldman]] (aunt)
[[Walter A. Haas Jr.]] (uncle)
[[Walter A. Haas]] (grandfather)
[[Abraham Haas]] (great-grandfather)
[[Douglas E. Goldman]] (cousin)
[[Robert D. Haas]] (cousin)
[[Betsy Haas Eisenhardt]] (cousin)
Walter J. Haas (cousin) | relations = | website = }} '''Peter E. Haas Jr.''' (born 1947) is an American businessman and philanthropist. ==Biography== Haas was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family in [[San Francisco]], the son of Josephine (née Baum) and [[Peter E. Haas]].[http://news.stanford.edu/news/2006/january11/haas-011106.html Stanford Report: "Peter Haas dead at 86; helped endow public service center" by MICHAEL PEÑA] December 14, 2005[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?pid=171391844 San Francisco Chronicle: "Josephine Haas July 5, 1914 - June 14, 2014"] June 19, 2014 He has two siblings: Margaret Haas Jones and Michael Stern Haas (predeceased).[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?pid=171391844 San Francisco Gate: "Josephine Haas (1914 - 2014)"][http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Levi-s-Bold-Plan-For-Reorganization-2994187.php San Francisco Gate: "Levi's Bold Plan For Reorganization" by Peter Sinton] February 13, 1996 He graduated from [[Stanford University]] in 1969.[http://news.stanford.edu/news/2007/august8/med-endowed-080807.html Stanford Report: "Three medical school faculty to receive endowed professorships" by Margarita Gallardo] August 8, 2007 In 1972, he was appointed as a manager at the [[Levi Strauss & Co|Levi Strauss Company]].[http://www.levistrauss.com/who-we-are/leadership/peter-e-haas-jr/ Levi Strauss Company website: "Peter E. Haas Jr."] retrieved October 12, 2014 Thereafter, he served in various capacities at the Levi Strauss Company. In 1980, he was named as Vice President and General Manager of the Menswear Division. In 1982, he was appointed Director of Materials Management for Levi Strauss USA. In 1996, he along with his father and uncle, Robert D. Haas, led a $2.5 billion leveraged buyout of Levi Strauss to ensure that it would remain in the control of the Haas family.[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/business/levi-strauss-stock-buyout-would-benefit-small-group.html New York Times: "Levi Strauss Stock Buyout Would Benefit Small Group" by James Sterngold] February 21, 1996 All employees and family members would decide if they wanted to hold their shares or sell. After the transaction, 95.2% of shares were held by Haas family members with 43% held by Haas, his father, and Robert D. Haas;[https://www.forbes.com/profile/haas/ Forbes: "Haas Family"] retrieved April 5, 2017 | "''Today, Peter Haas, Sr.'s widow, Mimi Haas, and his son, Peter Haas, Jr., who spent 17 years in managerial roles at the company, serve on the board of directors. Together with Peter's sister, Margaret E. Haas, and their cousin, Robert D. Haas, they own 43% of the company's shares''" and 12.4% by [[Rhoda Haas Goldman]]. Haas serves as either a director or trustee at the Levi Strauss Foundation, the Red Tab Foundation, the Joanne and Peter Haas Jr. Fund, the [[Walter A. Haas|Walter and Elise Haas]] Fund, the Novato Youth Center Honorary Board, Trustee Emeritus of the San Francisco Foundation (1996-2005), and Vice President of the Peter E. Haas Jr. Fund.[http://redtabfoundation.org/about/board-of-directors/ Red Tab Foundation: "Board of Directors: President Peter E. Haas Jr."] retrieved April 5. 2017[http://sff.org/about-tsff/who-we-are/board-of-trustees/ San Francisco Foundation: "BOARD OF TRUSTEES"] retrieved April 5, 2017[http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/THE-HAAS-LEGACY-How-one-family-s-generosity-and-2583444.php San Francisco Gate: "THE HAAS LEGACY / How one family's generosity and commitment to civic life are transforming the Bay Area" by Julian Guthrie] July 1, 2007 ==Personal life== Haas was married to Joanne Christensen[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?pid=165656958 San Francisco Chronicle: "Obituary - Gerald J. Christensen"] July 7, 2013[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?n=lorraine-m-christensen&pid=3458210 San Francisco Chronicle: "Obituary - Lorraine M. Christensen "] April 24, 2005 until her death. They had three children: Jennifer Haas, Daniel Haas, and Bradley Haas. He is remarried to Ginnie Haas. Haas also has two stepbrothers from his father's second marriage to Miriam "Mimi" Lurie: Ari Lurie and Daniel Lurie.[http://www.grindtv.com/transworld-business/features/high-line-festival-of-surfing-founder-ari-lurie-uniting-surf-culture/ Grind TV: "High Line Festival Of Surfing Founder Ari Lurie On Uniting Surf Culture" by Kailee Bradstreet] July 07, 2014[http://hauteliving.com/2016/01/one-on-one-with-daniel-lurie-ceo-of-tipping-point-community/598066/ Haute Living Magazine: "One-on-One with Daniel Lurie, CEO of Tipping Point Community" by Kelly E. Carter] January 8, 2016 Upon his father's death in 2005, his father's interest in Levi Strauss (worth $1.9 billion in 1999) was passed to Haas, his mother, and his sister. After the death of his mother in 2014, Haas and his sister inherited her shares in Levi Strauss. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{DEFAULTSORT:Haas, Peter E. Jr.}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Haas family]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Businesspeople from California]] [[Category:People from San Francisco]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Levi Strauss & Co. people]]

revision.comment: USA is deprecated, per [[MOS:NOTUSA]], and correct [[MOS:OVERLINK|overlinking]] of common places using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
Baron '''Philippe André Eugène Bodson''' (born 1944) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] businessman.
==Education== He graduated as civil engineer at the [[University of Liège]] (ULg) and obtained a Master of Business Administration at [[INSEAD]] ([[Fontainebleau]], France)
==Career== He started his career at [[McKinsey & Company|McKinsey]] in [[Paris]] where he worked for three years. He then worked for four years for the [[Daus Bank]] in Germany and the United States. In 1977, he started working for [[Glaverbel]], where he would be the [[CEO]] from 1980 until 1989. From September 1989 until December 1998, he was a non-executive member of the board of directors of [[Fortis (finance)|Fortis]]. From 1999 until 2003, he was a [[senator]] in the [[Belgian Senate]] for the [[Mouvement reformateur]]. Since 2004, he is a Director at Fortis, until 2010. In 2001, he was Chief Executive Officer of [[Lernout & Hauspie|Lernout & Hauspie Speech Product]].
In addition he is also a member of several other companies, such as: [[Exmar]] where he is President of the Board, he is a board member at [[Ashmore Energy]] (USA), CIB, President of [[Floridienne]], member of the advice committee of ''CSFB Europa'', ''Hermes Asset Management Europe'' Ltd., and of Cobepa/Cobehold. He currently also serves as the President of the BeCapital board, a cleantech private equity founded by Cobepa, Compagnie Financière Benjamin de Rothschild and BeCitizen. In the past he was a member of the [[think tank]] [[Coudenberg group]].
==Sources== * [http://www.senate.be/www/?MIval=/showSenator&ID=4125&LANG=fr Philippe Bodson] * [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2001_Jan_16/ai_69242511 Statement by Mr. Philippe Bodson on His Nomination as CEO of Lernout and Hauspie] * [http://www.freefairpost.com/pdf/CERP%20Forum%2004-Speech%20on%20Access%20to%20Network.pdf Speech for Philippe Bodson] - FFPI Conference * [http://becapitalpe.eu/governance/becapital-general-partner Bio of Philippe Bodson as Chairperson of BeCapital, a cleantech private equity fund]
{{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bodson, Philippe}} [[Category:Belgian businesspeople]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Liège alumni]] [[Category:INSEAD alumni]]
{{Belgium-business-bio-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox person | name = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Pierre Sylvain Désiré Gérard David-Weill | birth_date = March 8, 1900 | birth_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | death_date = January 14, 1975 (age 74) | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = French | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma_mater = | networth = | occupation = Banker | spouse = Berthe Haardt | children = [[Michel David-Weill]]
Eliane David-Weill | parents = Flora Raphael Weil
[[David David-Weill]] | relations = | website = }} '''Pierre David-Weill''' (8 March 1900 – 14 January 1975) was a [[France|French]] [[investment bank]]er. ==Early life== Pierre Sylvain Désiré Gérard David-Weill was born on 8 March 1900 in [[Paris]], [[France]]. His father, [[David David-Weill]] (1871-1952), was the Chairman of [[Lazard Frères]]; his mother was Flora Raphael. ==Career== David-Weill became a partner in the Paris office of the family's bank in 1927, when its Chairman was [[Raymond Philippe]]. Along with Lazard Frères minority partner, [[André Meyer]], Pierre David-Weill and his family fled the [[German occupation of France during World War II]] to the safety of the [[United States]]. There, he took charge of the firm's office in [[New York City]] where he remained until the liberation of France by [[Allies of World War II|Allied Forces]] in 1944. On his return to Paris, he left André Meyer in charge of American operations and along with [[Felix Rohatyn]], they expanded Lazard Frères business to make it a leading Euro-American investment bank. ==Personal life== David-Weill married Berthe Haardt in 1932. They had a son, [[Michel David-Weill]] (born 1932) and a daughter, Eliane David-Weill born in 1935. ==Death== Pierre David-Weill died in 1975. Despite converting to [[Catholicism]] in 1965,{{cite book |last1=Cohen|first1=William D.|title=The Last Tycoons: The Secret History of Lazard Freres & Co.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HyAStpnw2-C&pg=PA162&lpg=PA162&dq=#v=onepage&q=catholic&f=false|year=2007|publisher= Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|page=52-53|isbn=978-0385521772}} he is interred with his wife in the [[Jew]]ish section of the [[Cimetière du Montparnasse]] in the [[Montparnasse Quarter]] of Paris. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:David-Weill, Pierre}} [[Category:French Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Converts to Roman Catholicism from Judaism]] [[Category:French bankers]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:French Jews]] [[Category:French art collectors]] [[Category:Burials at Montparnasse Cemetery]] [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]]

revision.comment: /* Industrial Applications */
revision.text:
'''Product data management''' ('''PDM''') or [[Product information management|Product information management (PIM)]] is the business function often within [[product lifecycle management]] (PLM) that is responsible for the management and publication of [[Product (business)|product]] data.<ref>[http://www.npd-solutions.com/pdm.html Product Data Management/Product information management], Kenneth Crow</ref><ref>Ivica Crnkovic, Ulf Asklund, Annita Persson Dahlqvist "Implementing and Integrating Product Data Management and Software Configuration Management" {{ISBN|978-1580534987}}</ref> In software engineering, this is known as [[version control]]. The goals of product data management include ensuring all stakeholders share a common understanding, that confusion during the execution of the processes is minimized, and that the highest standards of quality controls are maintained.
== Introduction == Product data management is the use of software or other tools to track and control data related to a particular product. The data tracked usually involves the technical specifications of the product, specifications for manufacture and development, and the types of materials that will be required to produce goods. The use of product data management allows a company to track the various costs associated with the creation and launch of a product. Product data management is part of product lifecycle management and [[configuration management]], and is primarily used by engineers.
Within PDM the focus is on managing and tracking the creation, change and archive of all information related to a product. The information being stored and managed (on one or more file servers) will include engineering data such as [[computer-aided design]] (CAD) models, drawings and their associated documents.
Product data management (PDM) serves as a central knowledge repository for process and product history, and promotes integration and data exchange among all business users who interact with products — including project managers, engineers, sales people, buyers, and quality assurance teams.
The central database will also manage [[metadata]] such as owner of a file and release status of the components. The package will: control check-in and check-out of the product data to multi-user; carry out [[Change management (engineering)|engineering change management]] and release control on all versions/issues of components in a product; build and manipulate the product structure [[bill of materials]] (BOM) for assemblies; and assist in configurations management of product variants.
This enables automatic reports on product costs, etc. Furthermore, PDM enables companies producing complex products to spread product data into the entire [[product lifecycle management|PLM]] launch-process. This significantly enhances the effectiveness of the launch process.
Product data management is focused on capturing and maintaining information on products and/or services through its development and useful life. Typical information managed in the PDM module include *Brand name *Part number *Part description *Supplier/vendor *Vendor part number and description *Unit of measure *Cost/price *Schematic or CAD drawing *Material data-sheets
==Advantages==
* Track and manage all changes to product related data * Spend less time organizing and tracking design data * Improve productivity through reuse of product design data * Enhance collaboration * Helps using visual management
== Industrial Applications == Product Data Management is closely related and often used interchangeably with Product Information Management (PIM). PDM software applications are commonly used by companies involved with manufacturing and retailing. Examples of PDM software vendors include CMPRO,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://psasys.com/cmpro/|title=CMPRO - PSA, Inc.|work=PSA, Inc.|access-date=2017-11-19|language=en-US}}</ref> SOLIDWORKS,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.solidworks.com/sw/products/product-data-management/packages.htm|title=Packages|website=www.solidworks.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-19}}</ref> Zentail<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zentail.com|title=Sell on Jet.com, Walmart, Amazon, eBay, Google Shopping {{!}} Zentail|website=www.zentail.com|access-date=2017-11-19}}</ref> and Bintime/Gepard.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bintime.com|title=BINTIME provides a e-commerce development team, dedicated to your business goals|website=bintime.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-07}}</ref> Apart from those providers, in the market exist other kind of vendors that offer [https://saleslayer.com/product-data-management-pdm PDM systems] with extra functionalities such as Sales Layer.
== History ==
PDM stems from traditional engineering design activities that created product drawings and schematics on paper and using CAD tools to create parts lists (Bills of Material structures – BOM). The PDM and BOM data is used in enterprise resource planning ([[enterprise resource planning|ERP]]) systems to plan and coordinate all transactional operations of a company (sales order management, purchasing, cost accounting, logistics, etc.)
PDM is a subset of a larger concept of product lifecycle management ([[product lifecycle management|PLM]]). PLM encompasses the processes needed to launch new products ([[New product introduction|NPI]]), manage changes to existing products ([[engineering change notice|ECN]]/[[Engineering change order|ECO]]) and retire products at the end of their life ([[End-of-life (product)|EoL]]).
== References == {{Reflist}} [https://blog.saleslayer.com/how-to-select-pdm-system-in-5-simple-steps How to select a PDM system in 5 simple steps]
==Further reading== * {{cite web | last = Stark | first = John | title = Engineering Information Management Systems: Beyond CAD/CAM to Concurrent Engineering Support | publisher = Van Nostrand Reinhold |date=1992 | isbn=978-0442010751 }} * {{cite book|title=Product Lifecycle Management: Volume 1: 21st Century Paradigm for Product Realisation|last=Stark|first=John|publisher=Springer|year=2015|isbn=978-3-319-17439-6}}
==External links== * {{cite web | last = Miller | first = Ed | title = What is PDM | work = Mechanical Engineering Magazine | publisher = The American Society of Mechanical Engineers |date=October 1998 | url = http://www.memagazine.org/backissues/membersonly/october98/features/pdm/whatis.html | accessdate = 2008-01-23 }} * {{cite web | last = Wilson | first = David J. | title = How to Integrate Paper with CAD | work = Open Archive white paper | publisher = Open Archive white paper | url = http://openarchive.com/integrate_paper_with_cad.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-03-03 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061215152205/http://openarchive.com/integrate_paper_with_cad.pdf |archivedate = 2006-12-15}} * {{cite web | last = Sales Layer | first = | title = Diferencias entre un software de PLM (Product Lifecycle Management) y PDM (Product Data Management) | work = | publisher = Sales Layer |date= February 2018 | url = https://blog.saleslayer.com/es/diferencias-software-plm-pdm | accessdate = 2018-07-23 }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Product Data Management}} [[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Product lifecycle management]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox Governor | name = Robert Carter I | image = Robert Carter I.JPG | imagesize = 175px | order = | office = [[List of colonial governors of Virginia|Colonial Governor of Virginia]] | term_start = 1726 | term_end = 1727 | lieutenant = | predecessor = [[Hugh Drysdale]] | successor = [[Sir William Gooch, 1st Baronet|Sir William Gooch]] | order2 = 25th | office2 = Speaker of the Virginia House of Burgesses | term_start2 = 1696 | term_end2 = 1697 | predecessor2 = [[Philip Ludwell]] | successor2 = [[William Randolph]] | term_start3 = 1699 | term_end3 = 1699 | predecessor3 = William Randolph | successor3 = [[Peter Beverley]] | birth_date = 1662/63 | birth_place = [[Corotoman|Corotoman Plantation]], [[Lancaster County, Virginia]] | death_date = {{death date |df=yes| 1732 | 8 | 4}} | death_place = Lancaster County, Virginia | spouse = Judith Armistead
Betty Landon | children = 15, including [[Landon Carter]] | profession = | religion = }} '''Robert "King" Carter''' (1662/63 – 4 August 1732), of [[Lancaster County, Virginia|Lancaster County]], was an American businessman and [[colonist]] in Virginia and became one of the wealthiest men in the [[Thirteen Colonies|colonies]]. As President of the [[Governor's Council]] of the [[Virginia Colony]], he was acting [[List of colonial governors of Virginia|Governor of Virginia]] in 1726-1727 after the death in office of Governor [[Hugh Drysdale]].Brock, Robert Alonzo (1888). ''Virginia and Virginians'', Vol. I, p. 40. Richmond and Toledo: H.H. Hardesty. He acquired the [[moniker]] "King" from his wealth, political power, and autocratic business methods. == Biography == Robert Carter was born at [[Corotoman|Corotoman Plantation]] in [[Lancaster County, Virginia]], to John Carter (1613–1669) of London, England, and Sarah Ludlow (1635–1668) of Maiden Bradley, [[Wiltshire]]. In 1688, he married Judith Armistead of Hesse in [[Gloucester County, Virginia|Gloucester County]], an area which was included in the formation of [[Mathews County, Virginia|Mathews County]] in 1691.{{cite web |url=http://www.christchurch1735.org/history/robert_carter.html |title=History: Robert "King" Carter of Corotoman (1663-1732) |first= |last= |author=Foundation for Historic Christ Church |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work=Historic Christ Church |publisher=Historic Christ Church |location=Lancaster County, Virginia |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|doi= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031017121816/http://www.christchurch1735.org/history/robert_carter.html|archivedate=2003-10-17|accessdate=22 December 2010 |quote= |ref= |separator= |dead-url=yes |postscript=}} After her death in 1699, he married Elizabeth Landon in 1701. At age 28, Robert Carter entered the [[General Assembly of Virginia]] as a Burgess from Lancaster County, serving five consecutive years. In 1726, as President of the [[Governor's Council]], he served as acting [[Governor of Virginia]] after the death of Governor [[Hugh Drysdale]]. As an agent of [[Thomas Fairfax, 6th Lord Fairfax of Cameron]] – known simply as Lord Fairfax – he served two terms as agent for the [[Fairfax Proprietary]] of the [[Northern Neck]] of Virginia. During his first term, 1702–1711, he began to acquire large tracts of land for himself in the [[Rappahannock River]] region of Virginia. Carter acquired some {{convert|20000|acre|km2}}, a large part of which was the {{convert|6000|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[Nomini Hall Plantation]], also spelled "Nomoni" or "Nominy," which he purchased in 1709 from the heirs of Col. [[Nicholas Spencer]], cousin of the [[Baron Colepeper|Lords Culpeper]], from whom the Fairfaxes had inherited their Virginia holdings.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bFTkr8xU930C&pg=PA447|title=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography|author=|date=19 April 2018|publisher=Virginia Historical Society.|accessdate=19 April 2018|via=Google Books}} When he became representative of Fairfax's interests again in 1722, serving from 1722–32, he secured for his children and grandchildren about {{convert|110000|acre|km2}} in the Northern Neck, as well as additional land in Virginia west of the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]]. [[File:Nomini Hall Westmoreland County Virginia.jpg|thumb|left|200px|''Nomini Hall'', Carter family plantation in [[Westmoreland County, Virginia|Westmoreland County]]. Built in 1730 by Robert Carter II on land purchased by Robert Carter I]] Carter died on 4 August 1732, in [[Lancaster County, Virginia]], and was buried there at [[Christ Church (Lancaster)|Christ Church]]. He left his family 300,000 acres (1,200 km²) of land, 1,000 slaves and 10,000 British pounds in cash.{{cite web |url=http://members.tripod.com/~Bonestwo/index-17.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20081015141450/http://members.tripod.com/~Bonestwo/index-17.html |archivedate=15 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }} ==Legacy== When Lord Fairfax saw Carter's obituary in the London monthly ''[[The Gentleman's Magazine]]'', he was astonished to read of the immense personal wealth acquired by his resident land agent. Rather than name another Virginian to the position, Fairfax made arrangements to have his cousin, Colonel William Fairfax, move to Virginia to act as land agent, with the paid position of customs inspector (tax collector) for the Potomac River district. Fairfax himself then visited his vast Northern Neck Proprietary from 1735–37, and he moved there permanently in 1747. ==Descendants== Carter had five children with his first wife, Judith Armistead:{{cite book |last1=Garber |first1=Virginia Armistead |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=The Armistead family: 1635-1910 |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=21IbAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |year=1910 |month= |origyear= |publisher=Whittet & Shepperson Printers |location=Richmond, Virginia |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=30–33 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=John Armistead: The Second Son of William the Immigrant |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}} *Sarah Carter (born ~1690) *Elizabeth Carter (~1692-1734) married Nathaniel Burwell. *Judith Carter (born ~1694) died in infancy before her mother and buried near her at Christ Church *Judith Carter (1695–1750) married [[John Page (Middle Plantation)|Mann Page]]. *[[John Carter (Virginia politician)|John Carter]] (1696–1742) married Elizabeth Hill of [[Shirley Plantation]]{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Emory G.|title=John Carter (1695 or 1696–1742)|url=http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Carter_John_1695_or_1696-1742|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Virginia]]|accessdate=13 July 2015}} Carter had ten children with his second wife, Betty Landon: *Anne Carter (1702–1743) married [[Benjamin Harrison IV]]; (parents of [[Benjamin Harrison V]] and grandparents of President [[William Henry Harrison]]). *[[Robert Carter II]] (1704–1734) married Priscilla Churchill. *Sarah Carter (~1705–1705) *Betty Carter (~1705–1706) *[[Charles Carter (Virginia politician)|Charles Carter]] (1707–1764) married Anne Byrd, daughter of Col. [[William Byrd II]].{{cite web|last1=Ragsdale|first1=Bruce A.|title=Charles Carter (ca. 1707–1764)|url=http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Carter_Charles_ca_1707-1764|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Virginia]]|accessdate=13 July 2015}} *Ludlow Carter (born ~1709) *[[Landon Carter]] (1710–1778) married Maria Byrd, daughter of Col. [[William Byrd II]]. *Mary Carter (1712–1736) married George Braxton; (parents of [[Carter Braxton]]). *Lucy Carter (1715–1763) married Henry Fitzhugh *George Carter (1718–1742) Other notable descendants include: *[[Robert Burwell]] (1720-1777), grandson, member of the [[House of Burgesses]]{{cite web|last1=Tarter|first1=Brett|title=Robert Burwell (1720–1777)|url=http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Burwell_Robert_1720-1777|publisher=Encyclopedia Virginia|accessdate=15 July 2015}} *[[Robert Carter III]] (1727–1804) *[[Carter Braxton]], grandson, signer of Declaration of Independence *Talcott Eliason (1826–1896) J.E.B. Stuart's Field Surgeon during the Civil War;For Eliason's position as staff surgeon for J.E.B. Stuart's unit see [[Emory M. Thomas|Thomas, Emory M.]] ''Bold Dragoon: The Life of J.E.B. Stuart''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1986. {{ISBN|0-8061-3193-4}}. pp. 192, 236 *[[Robert E. Lee]] (1807–1870) [[Confederate States Army]] general. *[[Robert Randolph Carter]] (1825-1888), Confederate States Army first lieutenant *[[John Page (Virginia politician)|John Page]] (1743–1808) 13th Governor of Virginia. *[[Mann Page]] (1749–1781) Virginia delegate to the Continental Congress in 1777 *[[Thomas Nelson Page]] (1853–1922) US ambassador to Italy during the [[Woodrow Wilson]] administration. *[[William Nelson Page]] (1854–1932) American civil engineer and industrialist. *[[James "Gentleman Jim" Robinson]], one of the wealthiest African Americans in the Manassas area, but is also known because his homestead was located between the lines of the Confederate and Union armies during two major battles of the Civil War. == See also == {{Portal|Virginia|Biography|United States|North America|British Empire}} * [[Robert Carter III]] * [[Carter's Grove|Carter's Grove Plantation]] * [[Corotoman|Corotoman Plantation]] * [[Rosewell Plantation]] * [[Shirley Plantation]] * [[Slavery in the United States|History of slavery in the United States]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Robert "King" Carter}} * [http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Carter_Robert_ca_1664-1732 Robert Carter I] at ''[[Encyclopedia Virginia]]'' * [http://www.nominihall.com/ Nomini Hall Plantation] * [http://www.christchurch1735.org/history/robert_carter.html Robert Carter I] at [[Christ Church (Lancaster County, Virginia)|Christ Church]] * [http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/users/berkeley/ Diary, Correspondence, and Papers of Robert Carter] at the [[University of Virginia Library]] * [http://resgestae.up.krakow.pl/article/view/3235 Paweł Konieczny, Korespondencja Roberta „Króla” Cartera jako źródło do badań nad mentalnością elity osiemnastowiecznej Wirginii] {{VAColonialGov}} {{Speakers of the Virginia House of Burgesses}} {{Use British English|date=October 2010}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carter, Robert 01}} [[Category:1663 births]] [[Category:1732 deaths]] [[Category:American landowners]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American planters]] [[Category:American real estate businesspeople]] [[Category:Carter family of Virginia|Robert I]] [[Category:Colonial governors of Virginia]] [[Category:People from Lancaster County, Virginia]] [[Category:Speakers of the Virginia House of Burgesses]] [[Category:Virginia Governor's Council members]] [[Category:American slave owners]]
